In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. l.hi: Here bigynneth the Talys of CaūntꝰerbiryCompiled by Geffrei Chaucers

div.l: wHan that Aprile with his schoures soote
The drouthe of marche hathe persed þe rote
And bathed euery veyne in suche lycoue
Of which vertu engendred is þe floure
Whan zepherus eke with his swete breth .
Enspyred hath in euery holt and heth
The tender croppes and þe yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram his halfe course y ronne
And smale fowles make melody
That slepen all nyght with open yȝe
So pirikketh hem nature in her corages
Than longen folke to gone on pylgrymages
And Palmers for to seke straunge strondes
To ferne halowes kowthe in sondry londes
And specially from euꝰery schyres ende
Of Englond to Caunterbyry þey wende
The holy blysfull martir to seke
That hem hath holpen when þey were seke
Byfell that in that sesou vp on a day
In Southwerke at Tabard as y lay
Redy to wende on my pylgrymage
To Caunterbyry with full deuoute corage
At nyȝte was come in to that hostellery
Well xxix on a Company
Of Sondry folke by auenturez y falle
In felawschip and pylgrymes were þey alle
That toward Caunterbyry wold ryde
The Chaumbres / and stables were wyde
And well were esed at the best
And schortely whan the sonne was to rest
So had y spoken with hem euꝰerychone
That y was of here felawschip anone
And made forward erly to Aryse
To taken oure wey there as y yow devyse
But nathelese while y haue tyme and spase
Or that y further in this tale passe
Me thenketh hit acordaut to resou
To tellen yow alle the condicyou
Of yche of hem as semed me .
And which they were and of which degre
And eke in what aray þey were yn
And at a knyght than wol y furst bygyn
¶ A knyght þer was and þat a worthy man
That fro the tyme that he furst bygan
To Ryden oute he loued Chyualery
Treuth honour fredom and curtesye
Full worthy was he in his lordes werr
And þꝰer to had he Ryden dyuꝰerse cuntreys ⁊ ferr
As well in Crystendom as in hethenesse
And euꝰer honoured for his worthynesse
At Alysaunder he was whan hit was wonne
Full ofte tymes had he þe bord bygonne
Above all nacyoūns in Pruse .
In lettewe had he reysed and in Ruse
No crystenman ofter of his degre
In Garnade at the Sege eke had he be
In Algazir and ryden in Belmary
At lyeys was he and at Sataly
When they were wonne and in the grete see
At many a noble armes had he be
At mortayle Batayles he had be Fyftene .
And foughten for oure feith at Tramyssene .
In lystys thryes and ay slayn his foo
This worthy knyght had ben also
Sometyme with þe lord of Palatye
Ageyn a nother hethen in Turkye
And euꝰer had a Souꝰereyn pirise
And though he were worthy he was wyse
And of his porte as meke as ys a mayde
He neuꝰer ȝytte no velony sayde .
In alle his lyfe vn to no manꝰer wyght
He was a veray ꝑperfyte gentell knyght
For to tellen yow of his aray
His horse were goode but he was not gay
Off Fustyan he wered a Gyppou
All bysmoterd with his habergeou
For he was late come fro his vyage .
And wente for to doon his pylgrymage
¶ With hym ther was his sonne a yonge Sqwyer
A lover and a lusty Bacheler
With lokkes crulle as they were leyd in presse
Of twenty yere of Age he was as y gesse
Of his stature he was of even lenght
And wonderly delyuer of gret strenght
And he had somtyme be in Chyualery
In Flaundres Artoys and pykardy
And bare hym well as of so lytel spase .
Inne hope for to stonde in his lady grace
Enbrouderd was he as hit were a mede
Alle full of fresch floures white and rede
Syngynge he was or floytynge alle þe day
He was as fresche as ys þe moneth of may
Schorte was his goune with sleves longe and wyde
Well cowde he sytte on a goode horse and ryde
He cowde songes made and well endyte
Iuste and eke daunse purtrey and wryte
So hote he loued þat by nyght tale
He slepte no more þan doth a niȝtyngale
Curteys he was lowly and servysable
And kerfe byfor his fader at þe table .
¶ A yeman had he and ꝸseruauntꝭes no mo
At that tyme for hym luste ryde so
And he was cladde in cote and hode of grene
A Schefe of pekok arowes bryght and clene
Vnder his Belte he bare full thryftely
Well cowde he dresse his takel yemanly
His arowes drowped not with fedurs lowe
And in his hande he bare a myghty bowe
A notte hede had he with with broun vysage
Of wodecrafte well kowde he alle þe vsage
Vpon his Arme he bare a gay Braser
And by his syde a swerde and a Boclere
And on that oþꝰer syde a gay dagger
Harneysed well and scharpe as poynt of spere
A Crystofer on his brest of syluer schene
A horne he bare þe Bawdryk was of grene .
A Foster was he sothely as y gesse
¶ There was also A Nonne a pirioresse
That of hir smylynge was sympul ⁊ coy
Hur grettest othe was by seynt loy .
And sche was clepud madame Englentyn
Full well sche songe þe ꝸseruyse devyne
Entermuted in hur nose full semely
And Frensche sche spake full feire and fetusly
After the scole of Stratford at þe bowe
For Frensche of Parys was to hur vnknowe
At mete well y taught was sche with alle
Sche lete no mossell fro hur lypp9 falle
Ne wette hur Fyngres in hur sause depe
Well kowde sche kary a mossell ⁊ well kepe
That no drope ne fell vp on hur brest
In curtesy was sette full mych hur lyste
Hur ouꝰerlyppe wyped sche so clene
That in hur cuppe þꝰer was no ferthyng sene
Of grese when sche had dronken hur draught
Full semely after her mete sche raught
And sykerly sche was of grete dysporte
And ful plesaut and amyable of porte .
And peyned hur to counterfete chere
Of courte and for to be estately of manere
And to be holden dygne of Reuꝰerens
But for to speke of hur conscyens
Sche was so charytable and pytous
Sche wold wepe and sche had sene a Mows
Kaught in a trappe yf he were dede or bledde
Of smale houndes had sche þat sche fedde .
With Rosted flesch mylke and wastel bred
But sore wepte sche yf any of hem were dede
Or yf men smot hit with a yerde smertt
And all was conscyens and tender hert
Full semely hur wympull pynched was
Hur nose ful streyght hur yȝen grey as glasse
Her mouth ful smal and þꝰerto softe and rede
But sykerly sche had a fayre forhede
Hit was almost a span brod y trowe
For hardely sche was nought vndergrowe
Full fetys was hur cloke as y was war
Of smale corall aboute hur Arme sche bar
A peyre of Bedys gaudyed all wtith grene
And þer one henge a Broche of gold ful schene
On which þer was writon a crouned A
And after Amor vincit omia
A noþꝰer nonne with hur had sche
That was hur chapleyn ⁊ pꝰerstꝭes thre
¶ A monke þꝰer was a fayr for the maystry
An oute ryder þtat loued venery
A manly man to ben an abbot able
Ful many a deynte horse had he in stable
For when he rode men myȝt his brydel here
Gynglynge in a whistelyng wynde as cler
And eke as lowde as doth þe chapell belle
There as he was lord a keper of a Selle
The Rewle of seynt Maure or seynt Benet
By cause hit was old and somdele streyte
This monke let such old thyngꝭes passe
And held aftꝰer þe newe world9 pase
He yaffe nought of þat texte A pulled henne
That seyth that hunters be not holy men
Ne that a monke when he ys recheles
Ys lykened to a Fysche that ys waterlesse
This ys to sey a monke oute of his cloyster
But that texte helde nought worth a noyster
And y seyd his opynyou was goode
What schuld he studye and make hym self wode
Vp on a Boke alwey in cloyster to poure
Or swynke with his hondes and laboure
As Awstyn byddeth how schall þe world be obserued
Lette Austyn haue his swynke to hym reꝸserued
Therfor he was a prykasour Aryght
Greyhound9 he had as swyfte as foule in flyght
Of pirikkynge and huntynge for þe har
Was all his luste sette for no coste wold he spar
Y sygh his sleues purfyled at the honde
With grys and þat þe fynest of alond
And forto festen his hode vnder þe chynne
He had of gold wrought a full curyous pynne
A love knotte in the ende þꝰer was
Hys hede was balled þat schone as glasse
And eke his fase as he had be Anoynte
He was a lord full fatte and in gode poynte
Hys yȝen stepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a Furneys of lede
Hys botes sowple his horsez in gret Astate
Now certenly he was a feyre prelate
He nas not pale as a Forpyned goste
A Fatte swan loued he best of Any Roste.
His palfray was broun as a berye
¶ A Frere ther was also a wantone anda mery
A lymytoure a full solempne man
In alle theorders foure ys none that kan
So myche of dalyauns and fayre langage
He had made full many a maryage
Of yonge women at his own coste
Vn to his order he was a nobull poste
Full welbyloued and famulyer was he
With Francleyns ouꝰer alle in his cuntre
And with worthy wōmmen of the toun
For he had power of confessyoun
As he seyd hym selfe more þan A curate
For his order he was lycencyat
Full swetely herd he confessyou
And plesaunt was his absolucyou
He was an esy man to yeve penance
There as he wyste to haue a gode pytauns
For vn to a pore order for to yeve
Ys signe þat a man ys well schryve
For yf he yaffe he durst make avaunt
That he wyste þat man full repentaunt
For many a man so harde ys herte
He may not wepe althouȝe hym sore smert
Therfore in stede of wepyng and prayers
Men mote yeve syluer to þe pore Freres
Hys Typet was ay fassed full of knyves
And pynnes for to yeve fayre wyves
And certeynly he hade a mery note
Well cowde he synge and pley on the rote
Of such thyngꝭes bare he utterly þe pirise
His nekke was white as the floure delys
Therto he was stronge as a champyoun
He knewe the tauerners well in euꝰery toun
And euꝰery hosteler and tapster
Bettꝰer þan a laser or a begger
But he wold not dele with none such porayle
But all with rych folke and sellers of vytayle
And ouꝰer all there as profet schuld aryse
Curteys he was and lowly of ꝸseruyse
Ther nas no man nowhere so vertuouse
He was the best begger in his house
For þouȝe a wydow had not a scho
So plesaunt was his In pirincipio .
Yette wold he haue a halpeny or he went
His purchase was mych bettꝰer þan his rent
And rage he kowde as hit were a whelpe
In lovedayes coude he myche helpe
For ther he was not lyke a cloystrer
With a thredebare cope as a pore scoler
But he was lyke a mayster or a pope
Of dowbull worsted was his semy cope
That rounded as a Belle oute of þe presse
Somwhat he lypsed for his wantonesse
To make his Englysch swete vp on his tonge
And in his harpynge when þat he had songe
His yȝen twyncled in his hede Aryght
As don the sterres in the Frosty nyght
This worthy lymytoure was clepud huberd
¶ A Marchaunt also ther was with a forked berd
In motle and hiȝe on a horse he sate
Vp on his hede a Flaundres bever hatte
His Botes clapsud feyre and fetusly
His resoūns he spake full solempnely
Schewynge alwey the Encrese of his wynnynge
He wold þe see wer kepte for Any thynge
Bytwyxe myddeburgh and orewell
Well kowde he bye eschaunge and selle
This worthy man full well his wytte bysette
Ther wyste no wyght þat he was in dette .
So estately was he of his gouꝰernauns
With his Bargaynes and his chevyschaunse
Forsoth he was a worthy man with alle
But sothely to seyn y not how men hym calle
¶ A clerke þer was of Oxenford also
That vn to logyk had long y go
As lene was his horse y vndertake
And he was not ryght fatte y vndertake
But loked holowe and þer to soburly
Full thredebar was his ouꝰerest courteby
For he had goten hym no benefyse
Ne was so worldely to haue offyse
For hym was leuer to have at his beddus hede
Twenty bokes cladde in white ⁊ rede
Of Arystotle and his philosophie
Than Robes Riche fythel or Sawtry
But alle by þat he was philosopher
Yette hadde he but lyte gold in cofer
But all þat he myght of his Frend9 hente
On bokes and on lernynge he hit spente
And bysyly gan he for the soules pray
Of hem that fonde hym wherewith to scole ay
Of study toke he most cure and kepe
Nought oo word spake he more þan was nede
And þat was seyd in forme and reuꝰerens
And schorte and qwykke and full high of sentens
Sownynge in morall vertu was his speche
And gladely wold he lerne and gladly teche
¶ A Sergeaunt of lawe also war and wyse
That often tyme had ben at parvys
That was also full of excellense
Dyscrete he was and of gret Reuꝰerens
He semed such his wordes were so wyse
Iustyse he was full ofte in assyse
By patent and by comyssyou
For his scyens and for his hiȝe renoun
Off fees and Robes had he many one
So grete a purchaser nas nowher none
All was fee sympull to hy in effecte
His purchasynge myȝte nouȝte ben infecte
Nowhere so Byssy a man as he þꝰer nas
And yette he semed bysyer þan he was
In termes had he caas and domes alle .
That fro the tyme of kynge willam wer falle
Therto he kowde endyte and make a thynge
There kowde no wyght pynche at his wrytyng
And euꝰery statute kowde he pleyn by Rote
He rode but homely in A medle cote
Gyrde with a seynte of sylke with barr9 smale
Of his Aray tell y no lengꝰer tale
¶ A Francleyn was in þat company
White was his berde as is þe daysy
Of his complexyoun he was sangweyn
Well loued by the morow a soppe in wyne
To lyue in delyte euer was his wone
For he was Epyourues own son
That helde opynyou that pleyn delyte
Was veray felicite parfyte
An householder and þat a gret was he
Seynte Iulyan was he in his cuntre
Hys brede his ale was allwey after one
A Better envyned man was nowher none
Withoute Bakemete was neuꝰer his house
Of Fysche of Flesche and þat so plenteous
Hit sewed in his house of mete and drynke
Of alle deyntees þat men kowde thynke
After the sondry sesoūns of the yere
So chaunged he his mete ⁊ his soper
Full many a Fatte partrych had he in mewe
And many a Breme and many a luse in stewe
Wo was his coke but his sause were
Poynaūnt and scharp and redy all his ger
Hys tabull dormaūnt in his halle allewey
Stode redy keuꝰered all þe longe day
At Sessyoūns þer was he lord and sire
Full ofte tymes was he knyght of the schir
An Anelas and a Gypser all of sylke
Henge at his gurdul as white as mylke
A Schiref had he be and a comptoure
Was nowher such a worthy vauasour
¶ An haburdascher and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a Tapeser
And they wer clothed in o lyuere
Of a solempne and a grete fraternyte
Full fressche and newe her gere a pyked was
Her knyves were nought chapud with Brasse
But alle with syluer wrought full clene and wele
Her gurdels and her powches euꝰerydele
Well semed yche of hem a Feyre Burgesse
To sytte in a yeldehalle on a deys
Euꝰeryche for the wysdom þat he kan
Was schaply to ben an alderman
For goode had þey y nowh and rente
And eke her wyves wold þꝰerto assent
And elles certeyn þey were to blame .
Hyt ys full feyre to be clepud madame
And gone to vygylyes alle byfor
And haue a mantel ryally y bor
¶ A Cooke they had with hem for þe nones
To Boyle the Chykons with þe mary bones
And pouder Marchaunt tart and Galyngale
Well kowde he knowe a draught of gode london Ale
He kowde Roste sethe Boyle and frye
Make mortreux and well bake a pye
But harme hit was as thought me
That on his schyn a Marmole had he
For Blankemaunger þat made he wtith þe best
A Schipman was þꝰer wonynge ferr by west
For ought y wotte he was of dertemouth
He Rode vp on A Rounsy as he kowth
In a goune of faldynge vn to þe kne .
A dager hangynge in a lase had he
Aboute his nek vnder his Arme a doun
The hete somer had made his hewe al broun
And certeynly he was a gode felawe
Full many a draught of wyne had he drawe
From Burdeux ward while þe mꝰerchauntȝ slepte .
Of nyse conscyens toke he no kepe
Yf þat he faught and had þe hyȝer honde
By water sende he home schipp9 of dyuꝰerse lond
But of his crafte to reken wel his tydes
His stremes his daungers hym bysydes
Hys herborow his mone and his lodemenage
Ther nas none such fro hulle to cartage
Hardy he was and wyse to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berde be schake
He knewe all the hauenes as they were
Fro Gutlond to þe Cap Fenyster
And euꝰery Cryke in Breteyn and spayn
Hys Barge clepud was þe Maudeleyn
¶ With us þꝰer was a doctour of phisyk
In alle this world was þꝰer none hy lyke
To speke of Phisyke and surgery
For he was grounded in Astronomy
He kept his pacyens full gret dele
In owres by magyk naturell
Wel kowde he fortune the ascendent
Of his magyk for his pacyent
He knewe the cause of euꝰery malady
Were hit of hete colde moyste or drye
And where engenderd and of what humorur
He was a veray parfyte praktysour
The kawse y knowe and of his harme þe rote
A none he yaffe the sekeman his bote
Full redy had he his Apotecaryes
To sende hem drugges and letewaryes
For yche of hem made oþꝰer for to wynne
Hur Frendeschippes nas not newe to bygynne .
Well knewe he þe olde Escalapius
And discorides and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras halye and Galyen
Serapyou Razis and Amyen
Ameroys Damascien and Cōmstantyn
Bernard and Gatysden and Gylbertyn
Of his dyet mesurable was he
For hit was of no suꝑperfluyte .
But of grete noryschynge and degestible
Hys studye was but lytull on þe byble
In sangweyn he clad was all
Lyned with Taffata and sendall
And yette he was But esy of dyspense
He kepte þat he wan þat he wanne in pestyes
For gold in Physyk ys Acordyall
Therfore he loued gold in specyall
¶ A Goode wyfe þꝰer was of bysyde Bathe
But sche somdele def and þtat was skathe
Of cloth makyng sche had such a haunte
Sche passed hem of y pres and of Gaunt
In alle the parysch wyfe was þꝰernone
That to þe offrynge to for hur schuld gon
And yf þꝰer dyd certeyn wroth was sche
And full often oute of Charyte
Hur kerchyfs full fyne were of grounde
I durst swere they weyed ten pounde
That on a sonday were up on hur hede
Hur hosen were of fyne scarlet rede
Full streyȝte y tyed and schoes moyst ⁊ newe
Bolde was hur fase . fayre and Rody of hewe
Sche was a worthy woman all hur lyve
Husbondes at the church dore had sche had fyve
With oute oþer company in youthe
But þerof nedeth not to speke as nowth
Thryes had sche ben at Ierm
Sche had passed many a straunge strem
At Rome had sche be and at Boloigne
In Galys at seynte Iames and at Coloigne
Sche kowde myche of wandrynge by the wey
Gat tothed was sche sothely to sey
Vp on an aumbeler softely sche sate
Y wympled well and on hur hede a hatte
As Brode as ys a Boklere or a targe
A fotemantell aboute hur hypp9 large
And on hur feete a peyre of spurr9 scharp
In Felawschip well kowde sche lawgh ⁊ karpe
Of Remedyes of love sche knewe ꝑperchaunse
For sche knewe of þat arte þe old daunse
¶ A Goode man also þꝰer was of relygyoun
And was a pore ꝑpersou of A toune
But ryche he was of holy thought ⁊ werk
He was a lerned man and a clerk
That crystes Gospell trewly wold prech
Hys parysschons devoutely wold he teche
Benygne he was and wonder dyligent
And in aduꝰersite full pacyent
And such was he preved ofte sythes
Full loth were hym to curse for his tythes
But Rather wold he yeven oute of doute
Vn to his pore paryschons Aboute
Of his Offryngꝭes and his substauns
He kowthe in lytel haue suffysauns
Wyde was his parysch and housez ferr a sonder
But he ne lefte nought for reyn ne thonder
In sekenesse ne in myschef to vysyte
The ferrest in his paryssh mych and lyte
Vp on his feete and in his hond a staffe
This nobull ensaumpul to his schepe he yaffe
That furste he wrought and afterward taught
Oute of the Gospel he þe wordes caught
And this figure added eke þer to
That yf gold ruste what schal Iren doo
For yf a preste be foule in whom we truste
No wonder ys though a lewd man ruste
And schame hit ys yf a preste take kepe
A Schyton scheperd and a clene schepe
Well ought a preste ensaumpul to yeve
By his clennesse how þtat his schepe schuld lyve
He sette nought his benefyse to hyre
And lete his schepe acombred be in þe Myr
And ran to londou vn to powles
For to seke a Chauntery for sowles
Or with a Brederhede to be withold
But dwellud at home and kept his folde
So þat þe wolfe ne made hit not myssekarye
He was a Scheperd and not a Mercenary
And though he holy wer and vertuous
He was nought to syfull men dyspytous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his techynge dyscrete and benygne
To drawe folk to heuen by fayrenes
By goode Ensaumpul this was his byssynesse
But hit were . Any ꝑpersoūn obstynatt
What so he were of hiȝe or lowe estate
Hym wolde he snybbe scharpely for the nones
A Bettꝰer preste y trowe nowher none ys
He wayted aftur no pompe ne reuꝰerence
Ne maked hym a spysed conscyens
But crystes lore and his aposteles twelve
He taught but furst he folowed hyt hy selve
¶ With hym þꝰer was plowman his broder
That had y ladde of donge many a fother
And a trewe swynker and a gode was he
Lyuynge in pees and in ꝑperfite charyte
At all tymes þough he gamed or smerte
God loued he best with all his herte
And þan his neyȝtbur ryght as hym selve
He wold thressch and þꝰer to dyke and delve
For crystes sake for euꝰery pore wyght
With oute hir yf hit lay in his myght
His tythes payd he fayre and well
Both of his proper swynke ⁊ his catell
In a tabard he rode up on a mere
¶ There was also a Reve and a myller
A Sompnour and a pardoner also
A Mauncypull and my self þꝰer was no mo
The myller was a stoute carle for þe nones
Full bygge he was of Brawn and bones
That proued well for ouꝰer all þꝰer he com
At wrastelynge he wold haue awey þe Ram
He was schorte schulderd a thykke knarre
The nas no dor þtat he ne wold heve of harr
Or breke hit with rennyng with his hede
Hys berde as any sowe or foxe was rede .
And þꝰer to brode as hit were a spade
Vp on þe cop of his nose he had
A wert and þer on stode a tufte of herys
Rede as þe Brystel of a sowys erys
Hys nose thrylles blake were and wyde
A swerde and a Bocler bare he by his syde
His mouth as grete as a Furneys
He was a Iangler and a Golyardes
And þat was most of synne ⁊ harlotryes
Well kowthe he stele corne and tolle thryes
And yette he had a thoumbe of gold ꝑperde
A white cote and a blewe hode werud he
A Baggepype wel cowde he blewe ⁊ sowne .
And þꝰer with alle he brought us oute of þe toun
¶ A Gentel Mancyple þꝰer was of a temple
Of which acatours myste take ensaumple
For to be wyse in byenge of vytayle
For wheþꝰer þat he payd or toke by tayle
Algate he wayted so in his achate
That he was ay byfore and on gode astate
Now ys not þat of god a ful feir grace
That such a lewde mann9 wytte schal pase
The wysdom of a hepe of lerned men
Of Maysters had he mo þan thryes ten
That were of lawe expert and curyous
Of which þer was a doseyn in þat house
Worthy to be Stywardes of Rent ⁊ lond
Of Any lord þtat ys in Englond
To make hym lyue by his propur goode
In honoure dettelesse but he were wode
Or lyve as skarsely . as hym luste desyre
And able for to helpen alle a schire
In any case þat myght falle or happe
And yette this mauncyple sette all theyre capp
¶ The Reve was a sclender coleryk man
Hys berde was schave as nygh as euꝰer he kan
Hys here was by his eres full rounde y schorne
Hys toppe was dokked lyke a preste byforne
Full longe were his legges and lene
Y lyke a staffe þꝰer was no calfe seene
Well cowth he kepe a Garner or a bynne
Ther was none Audytour cowde on hy wynne
Well wyste he by the drought and reyn
The yeldynge of his seede and his greyne
Hys lordes schepe his nete his dayrye
Hys swyne his horse his store and pultry
Was holly in this Reves gouꝰernynge
And by his couenante yaffe he rekenynge
Sythen that his lord was xx yer of Age
There kowde no man brynge hym in Arrerage
There nas bayly herde noþꝰer hyne
But he ne knewe his sleyght and covyne
They were a dradde of hym as þe deth
Hys wonnyng was full feyre on a heth
With grene trees schadowed was his plase
He cowde bettꝰer þan his lord purchase
Full ryche was he astored pryvely
Hys lord he cowde ples sotelly
To yeve and lene hym of his own gode
And haue a thanke and yette a cote ⁊ hode
In youthe had he lerned a gode mystere
He was a gode wryght a Carpentere
This Reve sat vp on a well gode stotte
That was pomely grey and hight scotte
A longe surcote of pers he had
And by his syde he bare a rousty blade
Of Norfolk was this Reve of which ytell
By syde a toune men clepe baldeswell
Tukked he was as ys a Frere aboute
And euꝰer he Rode þe hyndrest of our rowte
¶ A Sompnour with us also þꝰer was
That had a fyry cherubynz fase
For sauseflem he was with yȝen narowe
As hote ⁊ lecherous as ys a sparowe
With scabbed browes blak and pylled berd
Of his vysage chylder were ofte aferde
There nas quyk syluer lytarge ne brymston
Boras Orsure ne oyle of tartꝰer none
Ne oynement þat wold clense ⁊ byte
That hym myght helpe of his whelkꝭes white
Nor of the knobbz syttyng of his chekes
Well loued he garlyk oynoūns ⁊ lekꝭes
And for to drynke stronge wyne rede as blod
Then wold he speke and crye as he were wode
And when that he well dronken had þe wyne
Then wolt he speke no word but latyn
A Fewe termes had he two or thre
That he had lerned oute of som degre
No wonder as he herde hit all þe day
And eke ye knowe well how þtat a iay
Kan clepe watte as wel as þe pope
But ho so cowthe hym in oþꝰer thyngꝭes grope
Then had he spende alle his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crye
He was a gentell harlot and a kynde
A Better felaw myght no man fynde
He wold suffer for a quarte of wyne
A gode felaw haue his concubyne
A twelfemoneth and excuse hym at fulle
Full piriuely a Fynche eke kowde he pulle
And yf he fonde owhere a gode felawe
He wold teche hym to haue none awe
In suche caase of þe Erchedekons curse
But yf mann9 soule be in his purse
Purse ys þe Erchedekons helle seid he
For in his purse he schuld punysched be
But well y wote he lyed ryght in dede
Of cursynge ought yche man hy to drede
For curse woll slee ryght as soylynge saveth
And also ware hym of a Significauit
In daunger had he at his own gyse
The yonge Gyrles of þe dyocyse
And knewe her counsell and all hur rede
A Garlond had he sette on his hede
As grete as hit were for an ale stake
A Bokler had he made hym of a kake .
¶ With hym þꝰer rode a gentel ꝑperdoner
Of Rouncyvale his Feende and his comper
That streyȝt was come fro þe court of Rome
Ful lowde songe he Come to me love cōmme
This sompnour bar to hy a styffe Burdoun
As of a trompe a gret sowne
This pardoner had here as yelow as wax
But smothe hit henge as do strykes of Flax
By ounces henge hys lokkꝭes þtat he had
And þerwith he his schuldrez ouꝰerspradde
But thynne hit lay by culpoūns one and one
But hode for iolyte wered he none
For hit was trussed up in his wallet
Hym thouȝte he rode all of þe newe gette
Discheueld saue his cappe he rode al bare
With glarynge yȝen had he as an hare
A vernycle had he sewed on his cappe
His walet byfore hym lay in his lappe
Bret full of pardou come fro Rome a hote
A voys had he as small as a gote
No berde ne had he ne neuꝰer schuld haue
All smothe hit was as hit were late schave
Y trowe he were a geldynge or a mare
But of his crafte fro Berwyk to War
Ne was þꝰer such a noþꝰer ꝑperdoner
For in his male he had a pyllewe bere
Which þat he seyd was oure lady veyle
He sayde he had a Gobbet of þe sayle
That seynt petur had when þat he went
Vp on the see tyll Ihu cryste hym hente
He had a crosse of latoūn full of stones
And in a Glasse he had pygges bones
But with þese relykꝭes when þtat he fonde
A pore ꝑpersou dwellyng up on lond
Vp on a day he gate hym more money
Then that þe ꝑpersou gate hy in moneth9 twey
And thus with feyned flaterynge ⁊ Iapes
He made þe ꝑpersou and þe pepul his Apes
But trewly to tellen at þe laste
He was A nobull ecclesiaste
Well he kowde he rede a lessoūn or a story
But alderbest he songe an Offerotory
For well he wyste when þat songe was songe
He most preche and well afyle his tonge
To wynne syluer as he well kowth
Therfore he songe so mery and lowde
¶ Now haue y tolde you sothely in A clause
The Estate þe Aray þe noumber and þe cause
Why þat assembled was this company
In Suthwerk at this gentel hostellery
That hight þe Tabard fast by the bell
But now ys tyme to you for to tell
How . þtat we beren us þat ilke nyȝte
When we were in the ostrye Alyght
And After woll y tell yow of our vyage
And all the reuenante of our pylgimage
But furst y pꝰery yow of your curtesye
That ye rette hit not my vyleny
To tellen her wordes and her chere
Though þat y pleynely speke in this mater
Ne thouȝe y speke her wordes ꝓproperly
For this ye knowe as wel as y
Who so schall tellen a tale after A man
He mot reherse as nyȝe as euꝰer he kan
Euꝰery worde yf hit be in his charge
Al speke he neuꝰer so rudely and large
Or elles mot he tell his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thyngꝭes or fynde wordes newe
He may not spare al thouȝe he were his broder
He most as well sey one worde as a nother
Also y pꝰery yow forȝyve hit me
All haue y not sette folke in hur degre
Here in this tale as þey schuld stonde
My wytte is schorte ye may vnderstonde
Grete chere made oure oste us euꝰerychone
And to soper sette us anonēm
He served us with vytayles at þe best
Stronge was þe wyne and well drynke us lyste
A Semely man oure oste was with alle
For to ben a Marchal in a halle
A large man he was with yȝen stepe
A fayrer Burgeys was none in chepe
Bolde of his speche wyse and wel taught
And of manhode hym lakked nought
Eke þꝰerto he was ryght A mery man
And after soper to pleyen he bygan
And spake of myrth amongꝭes oþer thyngꝭes
When that we had made our rekenyngꝭes
And seyd þus now lordyngꝭes truly
Ye ben to me welcome right hertely
For by my trouth yf y schal nought lye
Y syȝe not this yere so mery a company
At ones in this herborow as ys now
Fayn wold y done yow myrthes wyste y howe
And of a myrthe y am now bythought
To done yow ese and hit schal cost nought
Ye goon to Caunterbyry god yow spede
The blysfull Martir qwyte your mede
And well y wote as ye go by the wey
Ye schapen yow to talen ⁊ pley
For truly myrth ne counforte is none
To Ryde by the wey doumbe as a stone
And þꝰerfore woll y make yow dysporte
As y seyde erste and don yow som counforte
And yf ye lyke all by one assente
For to stonde at my Iugement
And for to wyrke all as y schall yow sey
To morow when we ryde by the wey
Now by my fader sowle þat is dede
But ye be mery y woll gyffe you my hed
Holde up youre handes with oute more speche
Oure counsell was not longe to seche
Vs thouȝte hit was noth worth to make hit wyse
And graunted hym with oute more avyse
And bad hym sey his verdyte as hy lyste
Lordyngꝭes quoth he now herkeneth for þe best
But take hit nought y paray yow in dysdeyne
This is the poynte to speke schorte ⁊ pleyn
That yche of yow to schorte with his wey
To kaunterbyry ward schall tell tales twey
Of auentures that haue byfalle
And which of yow þat bereth hym best of alle
That ys to seyn that telleth in this case
Tales of Best sentens and most solas
Schall haue a soper at oure aller cost
Here in this plase syttynge by this poste
When that we comen ageyn fro kaunterbyry
And for to make yow þe more mery
Y woll my selfe goodely with yow Ryde
Ryȝte at al myne own cost and be youre gyde
And whoso woll my Iugement with sey
Schall pay that we spend by the wey
And yf ye vouche safe that hit be so
Tell me anone with oute wordes mo
And I woll erly schape me therfore
This thynge was graunted and oure othes swore
With full gladde herte and preyen hym also
That he wolde vouchesafe for to doo so
And þat he wold be oure gouꝰernoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And sette a soper at a certeyn pryse
And we woll rewled be at his devyse
In high and lowgh and thus by one assent
We ben acorded to þe Iugement
And þꝰervpon the wyne was fette anone
And dronke and to reste wente euꝰerychone
With oute any lenger taryenge
A morow when the day gan sprynge
Vp rose oure oste and was oure alder kokke .
And gaderd us to geder in a flokke
And forth we ryden lytell more then a pase
Vn to the waterynge of seynt Thomas
And ther oure oste gan his horse areste
And seyd lordyngꝭes herken yf ye lyste
Ye woote youre for ward and y hit you record
Yf euensonge and morow songe acorde
Lete se now who schall tell the furst tale
As euer mot y drynke wyne or Ale
Who so be rebell to my Iugement
Schall pay for all that by the wey is spent
Now draweth cutte or that ye further twynne
Which that hath þe schortest cutte schall bygynne
¶ Sir knyght quoth he my maystꝰer ⁊ my lord
Now draweth cutte for for þat is myn acorde
Comethe nere quoth he my lady pirioresse
And ye ꝸser squyer lete be youre schamefastnesse
Ne studyeth not ley honde to euꝰery man
Anone to drawe euꝰery wyght bygan
And schortely to tellen as hit was
Were hit by aventure sorte or case
The soth is this þe kutte felle to the knyght
Of which blyth and gladde was euꝰery wyght
And tellen forth his tale hit is resou
By forward and composicyoun
As ye haue herde what nede wordes mo
And when this goode man sawh hit so
As he þat was wyse and obedyent
To kepen his forward by his fre assent
He seyd sythen y schall by gynne the game
What welkome be the cutte on goddes name
Now lete us ryde and herken what y sey
And with þat worde we ryde forth oure wey
And bygan with ryght a mery chere
His tals a none and seyd as ye may here

l.hi: Here endeth þe prolog of þis Boke

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte

(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe

(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe
(base) And thus with good hope / and herte blythe
(base) To Thebes / with olde walles wyde
(base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde

div.l: (base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily
(base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree
(base) He letted noght his felawe for to see
(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle

div.l: (base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue

(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame

(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth

(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour

(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /

(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye

(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace

(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent

div.l: (base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord

(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee

(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer

div.l: ¶ The Prolog of the Mylner
WHan that the Knyght his tale hath tolde
In all the company nas ther yonge ne old
That he ne seid hit was a noble story
And worthy to be drawe in memory
And namely the gentels euꝰerychone
Oure oste lowh and swore so mot y goone
This goth aryght vnbokled ys the male
Late see who schall telle a nother tale
For truly þe game ys well bygonne
Now tell ye sir squyer yf ye kon
Somwhat to quyte þe knyghtꝭes tale
The Myller that for dronken was pale
So that vnneth upon his horse he sate
He wold avale nother hoode ne hatte
Ne abyde no man for his curtesy
But in pylatꝭes voyse he gan to crye
And swore by armes blod and bones
I kan a noble tale for the nones
With which y wolt now quyte þe knyght his tale
Oure oste sawh that he was dronke of ale
And seyd abyde Robyn leve broder
Some bettꝰer man schall furst tell a noþꝰer
Abyde and lete us wyrke thryftely
By kokkꝭes soule quoth he þat wol not y
For y woll speke or ell go my wey
Oure oste seid sey on a deuelway
Thow art a fole þi wytte ys ouꝰercome
Now herken quoth þe myller all and some
But furst y make a protestacouūn
That y am dronke y know hit by my sown
And therfore yf y myssespeke or say
Wyte hit the ale of Suthwerk y you paray
For y woll tell a legend and a lyf
Both of a Carpenter and his wyf
How þat a clerke made þe wryght9 cappe
The Reve answerd and seyd hold þi clappe
Lette hit be thi lewde dronken harlotry
Hit ys a synne and eke gret foly
To appeyren any man or hym defame
And eke to brynge wyves in such a name
Thou mayst y nowh of oþꝰer thyngꝭes seyn
This dronke myller spake ful sone ageyn
And seyd leve broder Oswold
Who hath no wyfe ys no Cokewold
But y sey not þꝰerfore þat þu art one
Ther ben full goode wyves many one
Why art þu angry with my tale now
Y haue a wyfe ꝑperde as wel as þu
Yette nold y for þe oxen in my plowh
Take on me more þan y nowh
As demen on my self þat y were one
Y woll byleve þat y am nōmne
A husbond schall not be Inquysityf
Of goddꝭes pirivete ne of his wyf
So he may fynde godd9 fuson ther
Of þe reneunte nedeth not to Enquer
What schuld y sey mor but þe myller
He wold his wordes for no man forbere
But told his churlessch tale in þis maner
Me forthynketh y schall reherse it her
And therfor euꝰery gentel wyght y paray
Demeth not for godd9 love þat y sey
Of euel entent for y most reherse
Her tales be they better or wers
And who lyste not here hit chese a noþꝰer tale
For ye schull fynde y nowh grete ⁊ smale
Of historyall thyngꝭes þat longeth to gentelnesse
And eke of moralyte and holynesse
But the myller ys a cherle ⁊ þe Reve also
For harlotry þey told both two .
WHilom there was dwellyng in Oxenford
A Riche gnoffe that gestes helde to bord
And of his crafte he was a Carpentere
With hym þere was dwellynge a pore scoler
Had lerned arte but alle his Fantasye
Was turned to lerne Astrologye
And kowde a certeyn of conclusyoūns
To demen by Interrogacyous
Yf þat men asked hym in certeyn owres
When men schuld haue drought or schowres
Or yf men asked hym what schuld byfalle
Of euꝰery thyng men may not reken all
This clerk was clepud hende Nycolas
Of derne love he kowde and pirive solas
And þꝰerto he was slygh and full pirive
And lyke to a mayd meke for to see
A chaumber had he in that hostellery
Allone with outen any company
Full Fetusly dyght with herbez sote
His Almagyst and bokꝭes longyng to his art
His astrolaber and Augrym stones lyeng a parte
On schylves cowched at his beddes hede
His presse keuꝰerd with a faldyng rede
And all above þꝰer lay a gay sawtrye
On which he made on nyȝte melody
So swetely þat þe chaumber ronge
And Angelus ad virginem he songe
And after that he song þe kyngꝭes note
Full ofte blessud was his mery throte
And thus the swete clerk his tyme spent
Aftur his Frendes fyndyng and his rente
This carpenter had wedded a newe wyf
Which that he loued more than his lyf
Of xviij yere sche was of Age
Ielous he was and kept streyght in cage
For sche was wylde and yong and he was olde
And demyd hym self to be lyke a Cokold
He knewe not catou for his wytte was rude
That badde men schuld wedde hur symylytude
Men schuld wedde after her astate
For youthe and eld ys ofte at debate
But syth he was fallen in to þe snare
He most enduren as oþꝰer folk his care
Fayre was this yong wyf ⁊ þꝰer with alle
As any wesull gentell and smalle
A Seynte sche wered barred all of sylk
A Barme cloth sche wered as white as morn mylk
Vp on hur lendes full many a gore
White was hur smok and enbrowderd al byfore
And eke byhynde on hur coler aboute
Of blak sylk with in and with oute
The Tapes of hur white volyper
Were of þe same sute of hur coler
Hur fylet brod of sylk and sette ful hiȝe
And sykerly sche had a lykerous yȝe
Full small y pulled were hur browes two
And tho were bent as blak as any sloo
And softer sche was than woll of a weder
And by hur gurdel heng a purse of ledur
Tassed with sylke and perled wtith latou
In all this lond to seke up and doun
Ther ys no man þat kowde thenkh
So gay a poplote or a wenche
Full bryght was þe schynyng of hur hewe
Than in the toure the nobull forged all newe
But of hur songe hit was as lowd and yerne
As any swalow syttyng on a berne
Ther to kowd sche skyppe and make a game
As any kydde or kalf folowyng his dame
Hur mouth was swete as Braget or meth
Or horde of applez leyd in hey or heth
Wynsyng sche was and ioly as a colte
Longe as a maste and upward as abolte
A broche sche bare on hur love colere
As brode as a boos of a boclere
Hur schoes were lased on hur legg9us hiȝe
Sche was a pirimerose and a pygg9usnyȝe
For any lord to lyggen in his bedde
Or yette for any yeman to wedde
¶ Now ꝸser and eft ꝸser and so byfelle the case
That one a day this hend Nycolas
Fell with þis yong wyf to Rage and pley
While her husbond was at Osney
As clerkꝭes be full sotell and queynte

div.l: (base) As I haue thries in this shorte nyght
(base) Swyued the Milleris doghter bolt vp right
(base) Whil thow hast as a coward been agast
(base) Ye false harlot quod the Millere hast
(base) Ye false harlot hast thou so hest
(base) A false traytour false clerk quod he
(base) Thou shalt be deed by goddes dignytee
(base) Who dorste be so bold to disparage
(base) My doghter that is come of swich lynage
(base) And by the throte bolle he caughte Alayn
(base) And he hente hym despitously agayn
(base) And on the nose he smoot hym with his fest
(base) Doun ran the blody streem vp on his brest
(base) And on the floor with nose and mouth tobroke
(base) They walwen as doon two pigges in a poke
(base) And vp they goon and doun agayn anoon
(base) Til that the Millere sporned on a stoon
(base) And doun he fil bakward vp on his wyf
(base) That wiste no thyng of this nyce stryf
(base) For she was falle aslepe alitel wight
(base) With Iohn the clerk that waked hadde al nyght
(base) And with the fal out of hir sleep she brayde
(base) Help holy cros of Bromholm she sayde
(base) In manus tuas lord to thee I calle
(base) Awake Symond the feend is on me falle
(base) Myn herte is broken help I nam but ded
(base) Ther lyth oon vp on my wombe and vp myn hed
(base) Help Symkyn for the false clerkes fighte
(base) This Iohn sterte vp as faste as euere he myghte
(base) And graspeth by the walles to and fro
(base) To fynde a staf and she sterte vp also
(base) And knew the estres bet than dide this Iohn
(base) And by the wal a staf she foond anon
(base) And saugh a litel shymeryng of a light
(base) For at an hole in shoon the moone bright
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And by that light she saugh hem bothe two
(base) But sikerly she nyste who was who
(base) But as she saugh a whit thyng in hir Iye
(base) And whan she gan this white thyng espye
(base) She wende the clerk hadde wered a voluper
(base) And with the staf she drow ay ner and ner
(base) And wende han hit this Aleyn at the fulle
(base) And smoot the Millere on the piled skulle
(base) That doun he gooth and cryde harrow I dye
(base) Thise clerkes bette hym wel and lete hym lye
(base) And greithen hem and tooke hir hors anon
(base) And eek hir mele and on hir wey they gon
(base) And at the Mille yet they toke hir cake
(base) Of half a busshel flour ful wel ybake
(base) Thus is the proude Millere wel ybete
(base) And hath ylost the gryndyng of the whete
(base) And payed for the souper euerydel
(base) Of Aleyn and of Iohn that bette hym wel
(base) His wyf is swyued and his doghter als
(base) Lo which it is a Millere to be fals
(base) And therfore this prouerbe is seyd ful sooth
(base) Hym thar nat wene wel that yuele dooth
(base) A gilour shal hym self bigiled be
(base) And god that sitteth heighe in magestee
(base) Saue al this compaignie grete and smale
(base) Thus haue I quyt the Millere in my tale
(base) Here endeth the Reues tale
