div.l: THe Coke of Londou while the Reve spake
For ioy hym thouȝte he clawed hy on the bak
A ha quoth he for crystes passyou
This myller hath a scharp conclusyoūn
Vpon his argument of herbygage
Well seyd Salomou in his langage
Ne brynge not euꝰery man in to thi house
For herboryng by nyȝte is ꝑperylouse
Well ought a man avysed for to be
Whom that he brought in to his piriuete
I prey to god so gyffe me so row ⁊ care
yff euer sythen y hight hogge of ware
herd y myller bettꝰer sette a werke
he had a iape of malyce in the derke
And therfor yf ye vouchesafe to her
But god forbede that we stynte her
A tale of me that am a pore man
Y woll yow tell as well as I kan
A lytull Iape that felle in oure cyte
Our oste answered and seid y garaunt it the
Now tell on Roger loke that it be goode
For many a pastey hast þu lete blood
And many a Iakke of douꝰer hast þu sold
That hath twyes ben hote and twyes colde
Of many a pylgrym hast þu crystꝭes curse
For of thi ꝑpersely yet fare they þe worse
That they have eten wtith þe stubbel gose
For in thi schop goth many a flye lose
Now tell on gentel Roger by thi name
But yette y pꝰery the be not wroth for game
And therwith all he lowh and made gode cher
And seid his tale as ye schull after /here.
The Cokꝭes Tale;
A Prentys whilom dwelled in oure Cyte
And of crafte a vyteler was he
Gaylard he was as Goldefynche in the schawe
Broun as a Bery a proper schorte felawe
With lokkꝭes blake y kempte full fetysly
Daunse he kowde full well and Iolyly
That he was clepud perkyn Reuelour
He was as full of loue and ꝑperamour
As ys the hyue full of hony swete
Well was þe wenche with hym myght mete
At euꝰery brydale wold he synge and hoppe
He loued bettꝰer the Tauerne than the schop
For whan ther any Rydyng was in chepe
Oute of the schop thider wold he lepe
Tyll that he had all the sight yseyn
And daunsed wel he wold not com ageyn
And gederd hym a meyne of his sorte
To hoppe and synge and make such a dysporte
And þer they setten steuen for to mete
To pleyen at þe dyse in such a strete
For in the toun nas ther no prentys
That fayrer kowde caste a peyre of dyse
Than ꝑperkyn kowde and þꝰerto he was Fre
Of his dyspense in plase of piriuete
That fonde his maystꝰer wel in his chaffar
For ofte tyme he fonde his boxe full bare
For sykerly a prentys a Reuelour
That haunteth dyse Ryotte or ꝑperamorur
his maystꝰer schall in his schop abye.
All thouȝe he haue no parte of þe mynstralsye
For thefte and Ryot ben conuertyble
All gan he pley on Gyterne or rubyble
Reuel and trouth as in a low degre
They ben full wroth as all day men may see
This Ioly prentys with his mayste bode
Tyll he were nyȝe oute of his prentyshode
All were he snybbed erly and late
And somtyme ledde with Revel to newgate
But at the laste his mayster hym bythouȝte
Vpon a day when he his paper sought
Of a prouerbe that seith this same worde
Well bettꝰer ys Roten appull oute of a horde
Than it Rote all the Remenante
So fareth hit by a Ryotous ꝸseruante
hit ys lesse harme to let hym passe
Than he schende all the ꝸseruntꝭes in the plase
Therfor his maystꝰer yaf hym aquytaunce
And bad hym go with sorow and myschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentys had his leve.
Now lette hym Ryotte all the nyght or leve
And for ther is no thef with oute a loke
That helpeth hym to wasten and sowke
Of þat he brybe kan or borow may
Anonēm he sente his bedde and his aray
Vnto a comper of his own sorte
That loued dyse Revel and dysporte
And had a wyf that held for conutenans
A schop and swyued for hur sustynans
But her of woll y passe as now
And of Gamelyn y woll tell yow.

But her of woll I passe as now
And of Gamelyn I woll tell yow
Lithen and lysten and herken aryght
And ye schull herꝰer of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn of boundys was his name
He cowde of norture and mychel game
Thre sonn9 he had and with his body hem wan
The eldest was a mych schrewe and sone he bygan
His bredern loued wel her fader and of hy werꝰer a gast
The eldest deserved his fader curse at the last
The goode his fader lyued so yore
That deth was com hym to and handled hy sore
The goode knyght cared sore seke þer he lay
How his children schuld lyue after his day
He had ben wyde wherꝰer but no husbond he uas
All the lond that he had hit was purchase
Fayn wold he hit were dressed amongꝭes hem all
That yche of hem had his parte as it myȝte falle
Tho sente so he to Frendes squyers and knyghtꝭes
To helpen dele and dresse his londꝭes aryghtꝭes
And when his Frendes com werꝰer full stylle
He pꝰeryed hem to bere record of his last wylle
Iohn myn eldest son schall haue plowes fyve
That was my faders herytage while he was on lyve
And my myddelest son V plowes of lond
That y halpe forto gete wtith my right honde
And all myn oþꝰer purchase of londꝭes and ledꝭes
That y byquethe Gamelyn and all my god stedes
And I Byseche yow gode men that law kon of lond
For goddes love that my byquest stond
Thus dalte the knyght his londe by his day
Right on his deth bedde seke þꝰer he lay
And sone after he lay stone stylle
And dyed when hit was ciristes wylle
Anone as he was dede and y grave
Sone the older broder gyled the yong knave
He toke in to his hond his londe and his lede
And Gamelyn his yong brodꝰer to cloth and fede
He clothed hym and fedde hym evel ⁊ eke wroth
And lette his londꝭes forfare and his houses both
Hys parkꝭes and his woddꝭes and dyd no thyng well
And after he hit were bought on his own felle
So longe was Gamelyn in his broder halle
For the strengest of good wylle they douted hīn alle
Ther was noþꝰer therꝰer yonge ne olde
That wold wrath Gamelyn werꝰer he neuꝰer so bold
Gamelyn stode on a day on his broder yerde
And gan With his hond to handle his berde
Than thouȝhte he on his londꝭes that lay vnsowe
And his fayrꝰer okes that doun werꝰer drawe
His parkꝭes werꝰer broken and his derꝰer Reved
Of all his gode stedes was none hym byleved
His houses werꝰer vnhylled and vndight
Tho thouȝte Gamelyn hit went not aright
After com his broder walkyng therꝰer
And seid to Gamelyn ys oure mete yarꝰer
Tho wrathed hym Gamelyn ⁊ on hy gan loke
Thou schalt go loke þi self y woll not be thi koke
How broder Gamelyn how answerest þu me now
Thow spake neuꝰer such a word as þu dost now
By my faith said Gamelyn now me thenk nede
Of all the harmes that y haue y take neuꝰer hede
My parkꝭes ben broken and my derꝰer byreved
Of my armes and my stedes nought is me byleved
All þtat my fader me byquathe all goth to schame
And þꝰerforꝰer haue þu godd9 curse broder by thi name
Than spake his broder that Rape was of Rees
Stande stylle gadelyng and hold þi pees
Thow schalt be fayn to haue thi mete and wede
What spekest þu Gadelyng of lond or of lede
Than seide Gamelyn þe childe that was
Crystes curse mot he haue that clepeth me gadelyng
y am no worse gadelynge ne no worse wyght
But boren of a lady and geten of a knyght
Ne durste he not to Gamelyn neurꝰer a fote goo
But clepid to hym his men and seid to hem tho
Goth and beteth this Boy and reveth hym hys pryde
And lete hym lerne a nother tyme with me for to chide
Then byspake yonge Gamelyn
Crystes curse mot þu haue broder art þu myn
And yf y schalt algate be beten anōmne
Crystes curse mot þu haue but þu be one
And anōmne his broder in that gret hete
Made his men to fette staves Gamelyn to bete
When euꝰery of hem had a staffe y nomen
Gamelyn was ware tho and siȝe hem cōmmēmn
Tho Gamelyn syȝe hem come he loked ouꝰer all
And was ware of a pestel stondyng by the wall
Gamelyn was light and thider gan he lepe
And drof all his bredern men sone on a hepe
And loked as a wyld lyoun and leyed on goode wone
Tho his broder sight that he bygan to gon
And flye vp in to a lofte and schette þe dorꝰer faste
Thus Gamelyn with his pestel made hem al agaste
Sōmm for Gamelyn love and sōmme for eye
All they drowh hem to halues tho that Gamelyn did pley
What now seid Gamelyn euel mot ye the
Wolt ye bygynne contak and so sone flee
Gamelyn sought his broder whider he was flowh
And sawh wher he loked oute at a wyndowe
Broder seid Gamelyn com a lytel nere
And I woll teche the to play at the Boclerꝰer
His broder hym answerd and sworꝰer by seint Richerꝰer
While þe pestel is in thi hond y wol com no nerꝰer
Broder y woll make thi pees y sworꝰer by ciristꝭes ore
Caste awey the pestel and wrath the no morꝰer
I most nede seid Gamelyn wrath me at ones
For thow woldest make thi men to breke my bones
Ne had y mayn and myght in myn armes
To haue hem kepte fro me þey wold haue do me harmes
Gamelyn seyd his broder be þu not wroth
For to see the haue harme me werꝰer full loth
y ne dyd hit not broder but for a fondynge
For to loke yf þu werꝰer stronge and arte so ȝynge
Cōmme a doun then to me and graunt me my bone
Of one thyng I woll the aske and we schull sawte sone
Doun cōmme his broder that fykel was and felle
And was wonder sore aferd of þe pestell
He sayd broder Gamelyn aske me thi bone
And loke þu me blame but y graunte the sone
Then seid Gamelyn Broder y Wysse
And we schull be at one þu most grānnt me this
All that my fader me byquathe while he was alyve
Thou most doo me hit haue yf we schull not stryve
That schall þu haue Gamelyn y swerꝰer by ciristꝭes ore
All that þi fader þe byquathe þouȝe þu wold haue morꝰer
Thi lond that lyeth ley well hit schall be sowe
And thi houses Reysed up þtat lyen ful lowe
Thus seid þe knyght to Gamelyn wtith mouth
But he thought on falsenesse as he well cowth
The knyght thouȝte on treson and gamelyn on nōmne
And kyssed his broder and when they wer at one
Allas yong gamelyn no thyng he ne wyste
With such false treson his broder hym kyste
Lythen and lysten and holdeth yoꝰer tonge
And ye schull herꝰer talkyng of Gamelyn þe yonge
Ther was þꝰer bysyde cryed a wrastelyng
And þꝰerforꝰer was þꝰer sette a Ram and a rynge
And Gamelyn was in wyll to wend þꝰerto
For to preven his myght what he kowde doo
Broder seid Gamelyn by seynt Richerꝰer
Thow moste lene me to nyght a lytell courser
That is fressch to the spurr9 on for to ryde
Y most on a erande a lytel her bysyde
By god seid his Broder of stedes in my stalle
Go and chese the þe best and spare none of hem alle
And tell me gode broder while þu woll ryde
To a wrastelyne Broder here bysyde
Wyth worschip Broder werꝰer hit on to us all
Might y the Ram and þe Rynge brynge to hall
A stede þer was sadled smartely and skete
Gamelyn dyd a peyre of spurr9 fast on his feete
He sette his fote in styrop his stede þꝰer bystrode
And toward þe wrastelyng yong Gamelyn Rode
Tho gamelyn the yong was Ryde oute at gate
The false knyght his broder loked after that
And bysought Ihu ciriste heuen kynge
He myght breke his nekke at þtat wrastelynge
As sone as Gamelyn cam ther the plase was
He lyȝht a doun of his stede and stode on the gras
And therꝰer he herd a Francleyn welowey synge
And bygan byttꝰerly his hondes for to wrynge
Gode man seid Gamelyn whi makest þu þis farꝰer
Ys ther no man þat you myȝte helpe oute of care
Allas seid þe Francleyn þtat euꝰer was y borꝰer
For twey stalworth sonn9 y wene y haue y lorꝰer
A Champyon ys in the plase that hath wrought me sorow
Lest he slee my two sonn9 but yf god hem borowe
Y woll yeve x li by Ihu cryst and morꝰer
With þe nones y fonde a man to handle hym sorꝰer
Goode man seid Gamelyn wolt þu wel doon
Holde my horse while my man draweth of my schoon
And helpe my man to kepe my clot9 and my stede
And y woll in to the plase go to loke yf y may spede
By god seid þe Francleyn hit schal be doon
Y woll myself be thi man to drawe of thi schone
And wende þu in to the plase Ihu ciriste þe spede
And drede not of thi clothes ne of thi good stede
Barefote and vngyrte Gamelyn yn kam
Alle that werꝰer in þe plase hede of hym þey nam
How he durst aunter hym to done his myght
That was so doughty a Champyoun in wrastelyg ⁊ fiȝte
Vp sterte þe champyon Rapley ⁊ anōmne
Toward yong Gamelyn he bygan to gon
And seid who is þi fader and þi sirꝰer
For soth þu arte a gret fole þtat þu cam herꝰer
Gamelyn answerd þe champyon so me y thryve
Thou knewe well my Fader while he was on lyve
Sire Iohn a boundys was his name ⁊ y Gamelyn
Well I knew þi fader and mych of thi kyn
And thi selfe Gamelyn y woll that þu hit herꝰer
While þu were a yonge Boy a mych schrewe þu werꝰer
Than swerꝰer Gamelyn and swerꝰer by crystes ore
Now y am older wax þu schall fynde me a morꝰer
By god seid the champion welcom mot þu be
Come þu onys in my hond þu schall neuꝰer the
The champyon caste turnes to Gamelyn that was prest
And Gamelyn stode and bad hym do his best
Than seid Gamelyn to the Champyon
Thow art fast aboute to bryng me a doun
Now y haue proved many turnes of thyne
Thow most he seide prove one or two of myn
Gamelyn to the Champyon yede smertely anōmne
Of all the turnes that he kowth he schewed hy but one
And kest hym on the lyfte syde that iij Rybbes to brake
And þer to his one arme that yaffe a grete krakke
Then seid Gamelyn smertely anōmne
Schall hit be holde for a cast or elles for nōmne
By god seid the champyon wheþꝰer þat hit be
He that ones cometh in thi hond schall neuꝰer the
Than seid the Francleyn that had his sonn9 therꝰer
Blessed be thou Gamelyn þtat euꝰer þu cam here
The Champyon seid sith y ferst wrastled hit is yorꝰer
But y was neuꝰer in my lyf handled so sorꝰer
Gamelyn stode in þe plase anōmne with aute serke
Ys þꝰer any mo þtat wol com to werke
Ther was none with Gamelyn wold wrastle morꝰer
For he had handeld þe Champyon so wonderly sorꝰer
Two gentel men yemed þe plase
Cōmme they to gamelyn god gyffe hem gode grace
And seid to hym do on thi hosen and þi schone
For soth at þis tyme þu hast well don
And þen seid Gamelyn so mot y well farꝰer
I haue not yette haluendele sold my warꝰer
Then seid the champyon so brouke y my swerꝰer
He ys a fole that þꝰer of bieth þu sellest hit so derꝰer
Tho seid þe Francleyn that was in mych care
Felow he seid whi lakkest þu this warꝰer
By seynt Iame in Galys that many men haue sought
Yette hit ys to gode chep þat þu hast bought
Tho that wardeyns were of that wrastelynge
Com and brought Gamelyn the Ram ⁊ the rynge
And Gamelyn that was so ȝynge
Wente hōmme with mych ioy in the mornynge
His Broder sawh wher he cam with a grete Route
And bad schytte þe gate and holde hym ther oute
The porter of his lord was sore a gaste
And sterte anōmne to þe gate and lokked hit fast
Gamelyn cam ther to for to haue cōmme yn
Than was hit schette fast with a pyn
Than seid to þe porter Gamelyn seid vndoo the yate
For goode menn9 sonn9 stonden ther ate
Than sayd þe porter now by my berde
Thow schalt not com Gamelyn with in this yerde
Thow lyest seid Gamelyn and sworꝰer by his chyn
He smotte þe wyket with his fote ⁊ broke the pyn
The porter sigh hit myght no bettꝰer be
Sette fote on erth and fast gan to flee
By my fey seid Gamelyn that tarauell ys y lorꝰer
y am as lyght as þu þouȝe þu had hit sworꝰer
Gamelyn ouꝰertoke þe portꝰer and his tene wrake
And hitte hym so in the nekke that þe bone to brake
And toke hym by that one arme and threw hym in a welle
Vij xx fadom hit was depe as y haue herd telle
When Gamelyn þe yonge had pleyed his play
Alle that in yerde werꝰer drowh hem oute of þe way
They dredden hym full sore for werke that he wrought
And for the fayrꝰer company þtat he þider brought
Gamelyn yede to the gate and let it up wyde
He let in all that gon wold or Ryde
And seyd ye be welcōmme withoute any greve
For we woll be maystꝰerꝭes herꝰer and aske no man leve
Ȝysterday y lefte seid yonge Gamelyn
In my broder seller Fyve tonne of wyne
Y woll not that this company parte a twynne
And ye woll do aftꝰer me while any sope ys ther in
And yf my broder grucche or make foule cherꝰer
For mete or drynk while we ben herꝰer
Y am ourꝰer catourꝰer and berꝰer ourꝰer aller purse
He schalt haue for his grucchyng seynt mary curse
My broder ys a nygou y swere by crystꝭes ore
And we woll spend largely þat he hath spared yorꝰer
And who so that maketh grucchyng þtat we herꝰer dwelle
He schall to þe porter in to the drawe well
Vij. dayes and .vij. nyȝte gamelyn held feste
Wyth mych solas and no cheste
In a lytell toret his broder lay steke
And sigh hym waste his goode and durst not speke
Erly in a mornynge in the Viij day
The gestꝭes cōmme to gamelyn and wold go her way
Lordyngꝭes seid Gamelyn woll ye so hiȝe
All the wyne ys not dronk not her myȝe
Gamelyn in his herte was full woo
Whan his gestes toke her leve from hym for to go
He wold they had dwelled lengꝰerr but they seid nay
And bytaught Gamelyn god and good day
Thus made Gamelyn his Feste ⁊ brought wel to ende
And after his gestꝭes toke leve to wende
Alle the while that Gamelyn held his mangerye
Hys broder thouȝhte on hy be wreke with his trechery
Tho Gamelyn gestes werꝰer alle goone
Gamelyn stod allone frend had he nōmne
Tho after felle sone within a lytell stound
Gamelyn was taken wtith a wyle and hard y bound
Forth cōmme þe false knyght of the soler
To Gamelyn his broder he yede full nerꝰer
And seid to Gamelyn who made þe so bold
For to stroyen my store of my houshold
Broder seid Gamelyn wrath þe right nought
For hit ys many a day gon sith hit was bought
For broder þu hast had þis Xvj yerꝰer
Of Xv plowes by seynt Rycherꝰer
And of alle þe bestꝭes þu hast forth bredde
That my fader me byquathe on his deth bedde
Of all this Xvj yerꝰer y yeve þe prowe
For the mete and drynke we haue spende now
Than seid þe false knyght euell mot he thee
Herken broder Gamelyn what y schul gyf the
For of my broder body broder heyrꝰer haue y nōmne

(base) So ferde this gentil tercelet allas the day
(base) Thogh he were gentil born and fressh and gay
(base) And goodlich for to seen and humble and free
(base) He saw vpon a tyme a kyte flee
(base) And sodeynly he loued this kyte so
(base) That al his loue is clene fro me ago

div.l: (base) And hath his trouthe falsed in this wise
(base) Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir seruyse
(base) And I am lorn withouten remedye
(base) And with that word this Faukon gan to crye
(base) And swowned eft in Canacees barm
(base) Greet was the sorwe for the haukes harm
(base) That Canacee and alle hir wommen made
(base) They nyste how that they myghte the Faukon glade
(base) But Canacee hom bereth hire in hir lappe
(base) And softely in plastres gan hir wrappe
(base) Ther as she with hir beek hadde hurt hir selue
(base) Now kan nat Canacee but herbes delue
(base) Out of the grownd and maken saues newe
(base) Of herbes preciouse and fyn of hewe
(base) To heelen with this hauk fro day to nyght
(base) She dooth hir bisynesse and al hir myght
(base) And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
(base) And couered it with veluettes blue
(base) In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
(base) And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
(base) In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
(base) As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles
(base) Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
(base) And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
(base) Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
(base) I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
(base) Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn
(base) How that this Faukon gat hir loue ageyn
(base) Repentant as the storie telleth vs
(base) By mediacion of Cambalus
(base) The kynges sone of which I to yow tolde
(base) But hennes fort I wol my proces holde
(base) To speke of auentures and of batailles
(base) That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles

(base) That in his tyme many a Citee wan
(base) And after wol I speke of Algarsyf
(base) How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
(base) For whom ful ofte in gret peril he was
(base) Ne hadde he been holpen by the Steede of bras

(base) That faught in lystes with the bretheren two

div.l: The prolog off þe Marchaunde ~
IN Faith Squyer thow hast þe well quytte
And gentelly y prayse thi wytte
Quoth this marchaunt consyderyng þi youthe
So felyngly sir þu spekest sir y þe alowthe
As to my doome þer is none that is here
Of eloquence that schall be thi pere
Yf that þu lyue god gyue the good chaunse
And in vertu sende the contynuaunce
For of thi speche y haue grete deynte
I haue a sonne and by the Trynyte
I had leuer than xxtiri pound worth land
Thouȝe hit right now wer falle in my hond
He wer a man of such dyscrecyoun
As that ye ben Fye on possessyoun
But yf a man be vertuous with all
I haue my sōmne snybbed and yet schall
For he to vertu lyst not entende
But for to pleye at dyse and spende
And lese all that he hath ys his vsage
And hath lever talken with a page
Then to comine with any gentel wyght
Wher he myght lerne gentelnes aright
Strawe for your gentelnesse quoth our oste
What mꝰerchaunt sir ꝑperde well þu woste
That yche of yow mot tellen at þe lest
A Tale or two or broken ys byhest
That knowe y well sir quoth þe mꝰerchaunt certayn
I paray yow haue me nought in dysdeyn
Thouȝe to þis man y speke a word or two
Telle on thi Tale with oute wordes mo
Gladely sir oste quoth he y woll obeye
Vn to your wylle now herken what y sey
I woll not contrarye in no wyse
As ferr as my wytt9 woll suffyse
I paray to god hit may plese yow
Then wote y well hit ys gode y nouwh
The tale of þe Marchant
Whilom ther was dwellyng in lumbardy
A worthi knyght þtat borne was in pavye
In which he lyued in gret prosꝑperite
And lxtiri yere a wyfles man was he
And folowed ay his bodely delyte
On wōmmen there as was his appetite
As don these foles that ben seculer
And when that he was passed lxtiri yere
Were hit for holynes or dotage
I kan not sey but such a grete corage
Had þis knyght to be a weddud man
That day and nyght he doth al that he kan
To spyen wher he myght wedded be
Paraynge oure lord graunt hym þat he
Might ones knowe of þat blysseful lyf
That ys bytwyxe a hūnsbond and his wyf
And for to lyue vnder that holy bond
With which god man and woman to gedur bond .
None oþꝰer lyfe quoth he ys worth a bene
For wedlok ys so esy and so clene
That in this world hit ys a paradyse
Thus said þis olde knyght þat was so wyse
And certaynely as soth as god ys a kynge
To take a wyf it ys a gloryo9us thynge
And namely when a man ys old and hor
Then ys a wyfe the frute of his tresor
Then schuld he take a yonge wyf and a feyr
On which he myght engender his heyre
And lede his lyfe in ioy and in solace
Wher as these Bachelers syngen allas
When that they fynde any aduersite
In loue which nys but childes vanyte
And truly hit sytteth wel to be so
That Bachelers haue ofte peyn and woo
On brotyl grounde they bylde and brotylnesse
They fynde . when they wene sykernesse
They lyue but as byrde or a beste
In lyberte and vnder none areste
There as a wedded man in his estate
Lyueth a lyf Blysseful and ordynate
Vnder this yokke of maryage ybounde
Wel may his hert in ioy and blysse habound
For who kan be so buxom as ys a wyf
Who ys so trewe and eke so entendyf
To kepe hym seke and hoole as ys his make
For wele or woo sche wol hym nouȝte forsake
Sche ys not wery hym to loue and serve
Though he lye bedred tyl he sterve
And yete som clerkꝭes seyn hit ys not soo
Of which Theofraste ys one of tho
What forse thouȝe Theofraste lyste for to lye
Ne take no wyf quoth he for husbondrye
For to spare in household thi dyspense
A Trewe ꝸseruante doth more diligence
Thi gode to kepe then thyn own wyf
For sche wol clayme halfe parte al hur lyfe
And yf þu be seke so god me save
Thi veray Frendes or a knave
Wol kepe the bette þen sche þtat wayteth ay
After thy goode and hath do many a day
And yf þu take to the a wyfe
And lyfe in langour al thi lyfe
This sentence and an hundred thyngꝭes worse
Wryteth this man that god his bones curse
But take no kepe of al such vanyte
Defye Theofrast and herken me
A wyfe ys godd9 gyfte verayly
Al othur man yeftꝭes hardely
As londꝭes Rentes pastur or comune
Al moebles ben but yeftes of fortune
That passen as a schadowe up on the wal
But drede not yf y pleynely speke schal
A wyfe wol last and in thi house endure
Wel lengure then the lyste ꝑperauentur
Maryage ys a ful gret sacrament
He which hath no wyf y hold hym schente
He lyueth helpeles and al desolate
I speke of folke in seculer astate
And herken whi y sey not this for nought
That woman ys for mann9 help wrought
The hiȝe god when he Adam maked
And sawh hym allone bely naked
God of his grete goodenes seid than
Late us now make an help vn to this man
Lyke vn to hym selfe and then he made Eve
Here may ye see and her may ye pꝰerve
That a wyfe ys mann9 help ⁊ his counforte
Hys ꝑperadyse terrester and his desporte
So buxom and so vertuo9us ys sche
That þey most nedes lyue in vnyte
O Flessch they be and oo blode as y gesse
Hath but one hert in wele and in distresse
A wyfe a seynt mary Benedicite
How myght a man haue any aduꝰersyte
That hath a wyfe certes y kan not sey
The Blysse which ys bytwyxe hem twey
Ther may no tonge telle ne hert thenke
Yf he be por sche helpeth hym to swynk
Sche keputh his goode and wasteth neu a dele
Al þat hur husbond luste sche lyketh wel
Sche saith not ones nay when he saith yee
Do this dame saith he / al redy sir saith sche
O blysseful Ordre / oo wedlok so pꝰercyous
Thou art so mery and eke so vertuous
And so comended and approued eke
That any man that holt hy worth aleke
Vp on his bare knees ought al his lyfe
Thanken his god that hym hath sende a wyfe
Or elles paray god hym for to send
A wyfe to laste to his lyues ende
For then his lyf ys sette in sykernesse
He may not be deceyued as y gesse
So that he wyrke after hys wyues rede
Then may he boldely kepe up his hede
They ben so trewe and þꝰerwith also wyse
For which yf þu wol werken as the wyse
Do alway as women wol the rede
/ / Lo how þat Iacob as clerkꝭes rede
By goode counsel of his moder rebekke
Bonde þe kyddes skyn aboute his nekke
For which his fader benysoun he wan
/ / Lo Iudith as the story tel kan
By goode counsel sche godd9 pepul kepte
And slowh hym olyfernus while he slepte
Loo Abygayle by goode counsel how he
Saved hur husbond when þat he
Schul haue be slayn and loke Ester also
By goode counsel delyuꝰerd oute of wo
The pepul of god and made hym mardochee
Of Assuer enhaunsed for to bee
/ / Ther is no thynge in grete suꝑperlatyf
As seith senek above an humble wyf
Suffer thy wyves tonge as Catoūn bytte
Sche schal comaunde and þu schal suffer hit
And yet sche wol obeyen of Curtesye
/ / A wyfe ys keper of thyn husbondrye
Wel may þe seeke man bywayle and wepe
Ther as ther ys no wyfe þe house to kepe
I warne the yf þu wysely wolt wyrche
Love wel thi wyf as ciriste loueth his chirch
Yf þu louest þi self þu louest þi wyfe
No man hateth his Flesch / / but in his lyfe
He fostreth hit and þerfore bydde y the
Cheryssch thi wyfe or thow schal neuꝰer thee
Husbond and wyf what so men Iape or play
Of worldely folk holden þe syker wey
They ben so knytte þꝰer may no harme bytyde
And namely up on the wyves syde
For which this Ianuary of whom y told
Consydred hath with in his day9 olde
The lusty lyfe the vertuous quyete
That is in maryage so hony swete
And for his Frendes on a day he sente
To telle hem the effecte of his Entente
/ With fase sadde his tale he hath hem tolde
He sayd Frendes y am hore and olde
And almost god it wote on my pytt9 brynke
Vp on my soule somwhat most y thenke
I haue my body folyly dyspended
Blessud be god that hit schal be mended
For y wol be certayn a weddud man
And þat anone in al the hast that y kan
Vn to some maiden fayre and tender of age
Y pray yow schapeth for my maryage
Alle sodeynly for y wol not abyde
And y wol fonde to aspyen on my syde
To whom y may be wedded hastely
But for as myche as ye ben mo then y
Ye schul Rather such a thynge aspyen
Then y and where me best wer to alyen
/ / But oo thynge y warne yow my Frendes der
I wol none olde wyfe in no manere
Sche schal not passe twenty yere certayn
Olde Fysch and yonge Flesch wold y fayn
Bettꝰer ys quoth he a pyke then a pykerel
And bettꝰer then þe old bef ys the tender vele
Y wol no woman of Fyfty yere of Age
Hit is but as bene strawe and gret forage
And eke þese olde wydowes god hit wote
They kon so mych crafte on wades bote
So mych broken harme when hem lyste
With hem schuld y neuꝰer lyve in rest
For sondry scoles maketh sotel clerkꝭes
Woman of many scoles half a clerke sche ys
But certayn a yonge thynge may men gye
Ryght as men may with warme waxe plye
Wherfore y say yow schortely in a clause
Y wol none old wyfe for this cause
For yf so were y had such myschaunse
That y in hur kowde haue no plesaunce
Then schuld y lede my lyf in aduontrye
And streyght to þe deuel when y dye
Ne childer schuld y none up on hur geten
Yette were me lever houndez had me eten
Then that my herytage schuld falle
In straunge hand9 and þus y tel yow alle
Y dote not y wote þe cause why
Men schuld wedde and furthermor wote y
Ther speketh many of maryage
That wote no more of hit þan wote my page
For which causez man schuld take a wyfe
Yf he may not lyve chaste in his lyfe
Take hym a with grete deuocyoun
By cause of leful procreacyoun
Of childer to the honour of god above
And not onely for ꝑperamour of love
And for they schuld lechery eschewe
And yelde hur dette when hit ys dewe
Or for yche of hem schuld helpen oþꝰer
In myschef as a sustꝰer schal þe broder
And lyue in chastite ful holyly
But sires by your leve þat am not y
For god be thanked y dar make avaunte
I fele my lymes starke and suffysaunt
To do alle that a man longeth to
Y wote my selfe best what y may doo
Thouȝe y be hore y fare as doth a tree
That blossemeth or the Frute waxen be
And a blossemyng tree ys neyþꝰer drye ne dede
Y fele me nowhere hore saf on my hede
My herte and al my lymmes ben as grene
As laurer thorou the yere ys for to sene
And sythen that ye haue herd myn entente
Y paray yow to my counsel ye wol assent
Dyuꝰerse men dyuersly hym told
Of maryage many ensaumples old
Som blamed hit som praysed hit certayn
But at the last schortely to seyn
As al day falleth altercacyoun
Bytwene frendes in dysputacoun
There felle a stryfe bytwene his bredern two
Off which that one was clepud placebo
Iustinus sothely called was that oþꝰer
/ / Placebo seid oo Ianuary broder
Ful lytel nede had ye my lord so dere
Counsel to aske of any that is here
But that ye ben so ful of sapyence
That ye ne lyketh for your hiȝe pudence
To weyuen fro the word of Salamon
This word seid he to us euerychone
Werke al thynge by counsel þus said he
And þen schal þu not repent the
But though þat Salamon spake such a word
Myn own dere broder and my lord
So wyssely god my soule bryng to rest
I holde youre own counsel ys the best
A ful grete fole ys any counseillour
That serveth any lord of hiȝe honour
That dar pꝰersume or thenk hit
That his counsel schuld passe his lordes wytte
Nay lordes be no foles by my fay
Ye haue youre selven schewed here to day
So hiȝe sentence so holyly and wel
That y consent and conferme euꝰery dele
Youre wordes al and your opynyou
By god þꝰer is no man in al this toun
Ne in ytaile kowde bettꝰer haue sayd
Cryst held hym of this counsel ful wel payd
And trewly hit ys an hiȝe corage
Of any man that stopen ys in age
To take a yonge wyfe by my fader kyn
Youre hert hangeth on a ioyly pyn
Doth in this mater as you lyste
For Fynally y hold youre own counsel best
/ / Iustynus his brodr þat ay sate stylle and herd
Ryght in this wyse to placebo answerd
Now broder myne be pacyent y you paray
Syth ye haue seid herken what y say
/ / Senek amonge oþꝰer wordes wyse
Seith a man ought hym ryght wel avyse
To whom he yeveth his lond or his catel
And sythen y ought avyse me right wel
To whom y yeve my goode awey fro me
Wel mych more y ought avyse me
To whom y yeve my body for alwey
Y warne you wel hit ys no childes play
To taken a wyfe withoute avysement
Men most enquere this ys myn assent
Wheþꝰer sche be wyse sober or drunclewe
Or proude or oþer wayes a schrewe
A Chyder or a waster of thi goode
Or riche or pore or mannysch wode
Al be hit so that no man fynde schal
None in this worlde that trotteth hole in al
Ne man ne best such as men kowde devyse
But natheles it ought y nowh to suffyse
With any wyfe yf so wer that sche had
Mo gode thewes then her vices badde
And al this asketh leyser to enquer
For god wote y haue wept ful many a teer
Ful pryvely syth y had a wyfe
Prayse who so wol a weddud mann9 lyf
Certayn y fynde in hit but coste and care
Of Obseruancꝭes and al blyssez bare
And yette god wotte my neyghtburs aboute
And namely of women many a rowte
Seyn that I haue the most stedefast wyf
And eke þe mekest that bereth lyfe
But y wote best where wryngeth me my scho
Ye may for me right as ye luste doo
Avyseth yow ye ben a man of age
How ye entren in to maryage
And namely with a yong wyfe and a feire
By hym that made water erth and eyre
The yongest man that is in al this rowte
Ys besy ynowh to bryngen hit abowte
To haue his wyfe allone trusteth me
Ye schul not plese hur fully yeres thre
This ys to sayn to don hur ful plesaunce
A wyf asketh ful many an obseruance
Y pray you that ye be not yuel a payd
/ / Wel quoth this Ianuarye hast þu sayd
Strawe for thi senek and þi prouerbes
I kounte not a panyer ful of Erbes
Of scole terme wyser þen thow
As þu hast herd assented right now
To my purpose broder placebo what sey ye
/ / I say it is a cursed man quoth he
That letteth matirimony sykerly
And with þat worde they rysen sodeynly
And ben assented fully that he schuld
Be wedded when hym luste and where he wold
/ / High fantasye and curyous byssynesse
Fro day to day gan in the soule Impresse
Of Ianuarye aboute his maryage
Many a feyre schap and many a feyr vysage
Ther passeth thorow his hert nyght by nyght
As who so toke a myrrorur polyssched bryght
And sette it in a conune market plase
Then schuld he see many a fygure ⁊ fase
By his myrrour and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuary with in his thought deuyse
Of maydons which dwellud hym bysyde
He wyste not where he myght abyde
For yf that one haue beawte in hur fase
A noþer stant so in þe peples grace
For hur sadnesse and hur benygnyte
That of the peple grettest voys hath sche
And some were riche and had bad name
But natheles bytwene ernest and game
He at þe last apoynted hym on one
And lete al othur fro his hert goon
And chese hur of his own autorite
For loue ys blynd alday and may not see
And when that he was in his bedde brought
He portrayed in his hert and thought
Hur Fressch bewte . and hur age tender
Hur myddel smal hur armes long and sclender
Hur wyse gouernaunce hur gentelnesse
Hur womanly beryng and hur sadenesse
And when þat he on hur was condescended
Hym thought his choyse myght not be amended
For when that he hym self concluded had
Hym thought yche oþꝰer mann9 wytte was badde
That Impossible hit were to replye
Ageyn his choys this was his fantasye
/ / His Frendes sente he to at his Instaunce
And prayed hem to done hym that plesaunce
That hastely þey wolden to hym come
He wold abrygge her laboure al and some
Nedeth no more for hym to goo ne ryde
He was apoynted þere he wold abyde
Placebo came and eke his Frendez sone
And alderfurst he bad hem a bone
That none of hem none argumēmtz make
Ageyn the purpose which he hath take
Which purpose was plesyng to god seid he
And veray ground of prosꝑperite
And said þer was a maydon in þtat toun
Which þat of bewte had gret renoun
Al were hit so sche were of smale degre
Suffyseth hy hur youthe and bewte
Which mayde he seid he wold haue to his wyfe
To lede in ese and holynes his lyf
And thanked god þat he myght haue hur alle
That no wyght his blysse ꝑperseyve schal
And preyed to hem to laboure in this nede
And schapen þat he fayle not to spede
For þen he said þat his spyryte was at ese
Than ys no thyng quoth he þtat may dysplese
Save one thyng pirikketh in my conscyence
The which y wol reherse yn youre pꝰersence
I haue quoth he herd say ful yore a goo
Ther may no man haue ꝑperfite blyssez two
That is to sey in erth and eke in heuen
For thouȝe he kepe hym fro the synn9 seven
There ys so grete Felicite ese and luste yn maryage
That euer y am a gaste now in myn age
That y schal lede so myry a lyfe
So delycate with outen wo or stryfe
That y schal my heuen in erth here
For sith that heuen ys bought so dere
With tribulacoun and gret penance
How schuld y þat schal lyue in such plesaunce
As al wedded men don with her wyues
Come to the blysse þꝰer cryste etꝰerne alyue ys
This ys my drede and ye my bredren twey
Assoyleth me this questyoun y you paray
/ / Iustynus his older broder þat hateth his foly
Answerd a none ryght in his Iapery
For he wold his longe tale abregge
He wold none autoryte alegge
And seid ꝸser so þꝰer be none oþꝰer obstacle
Othur than this god of his hiȝe myracul
And of his mꝰercy may so for yow wyrche
That er ye haue youre ryghtes of holychurch
Ye may repent of wedded mann9 lyf
In which ye say þꝰer is no man stryf
And elles god forbede but he sent
A wedded grace to repent
Wel often rather than a sengul man
And þꝰerfore sir þe best rede þat y kan
Dyspeyre yow not but haue in yorur memory
ꝐPerauentur sche may be yorur purgatory
Sche may be godd9 mene and godd9 whippe
Then schal youre soule to heuen skyppe
Swyther than doth an arow of a bowh
Y hope to god heraftꝰer schul ye knowe
That þꝰer is none so grete felicyte
In maryage ne neuꝰer schal be .
That yow schal lette of youre salvacyoun
So þat ye vse as skylle and Resoun
The lustes of youre wyf attemꝑperally
That ye plese hur not to amerously
And þat ye kepe you fro oþꝰer synne
My tale ys don my wytte ys thyn
And with that Iustyn and his broder
Haue take hur leve and eche of hem of oþꝰer
And when þey sawh hit most nedes be
They wroughten so bysely and wyse trete
That sche this maydon that Mayus hight
As hastely as euꝰer that sche myȝte
Schal be wedded to þis knyȝt Ianuary
Y trowe hit wer ful long for yow to tary
Yf y you told of euꝰery sciripte and bond
By which sche was Feffud in his lond
Or for telle of hur riche array
But fynally comen ys the day
That to þe church both ben they wente
For to Resseyue the holy sacament
Thus ben they wedded with solempnyte
And aftꝰer sytteth he and sche
With oþꝰer worthy estate and folk on þe deyse

(base) Pouerte ful often whan a man is lowe
(base) Maketh hymself and eek his god to knowe
(base) Pouerte a spectacle is as thynketh me
(base) Thurgh which he may his verray freendes se
(base) And therfore sire syn that I noght yow greue
(base) Of my pouerte namoore ye me repreue
(base) Now sire of elde ye repreue me
(base) And certes sire thogh noon auctoritee
(base) Were in no book ye gentils of honour
(base) Seyn that men an old wight sholde doon fauour
(base) And clepe hym fader for youre gentilesse
(base) And Auctours shal I fynden as I gesse
(base) Now ther ye seye that I am foul and old
(base) Thanne drede yow noght to been a Cokewold
(base) For filthe and elde also mote I thee
(base) Been grete wardeyns vpon chastitee
(base) But nathelees syn I knowe youre delit
(base) I shal fulfille youre worldly appetit
(base) Chees now quod she oon of thise thynges tweye
(base) To han me foul and old til that I deye
(base) And be to yow a trewe humble wyf
(base) And neuere yow displese in al my lyf
(base) Or ellis ye wol han me yong and fair
(base) And take youre auenture of the repair
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
(base) Or in som oother place may wel be
(base) Now chees your seluen wheither that yow liketh
(base) This knyght auyseth hym and soore siketh
(base) But atte laste he seyde in this manere
(base) My lady and my loue and wyf so deere
(base) I putte me in youre wise gouernaunce
(base) Cheseth youre self which that may be moost plesaunce
(base) And moost honour to yow and me also
(base) I do no fors the wheither of the two
(base) For as yow liketh it suffiseth me
(base) Thanne haue I gete of yow maistrye quod she
(base) Syn I may chese and gouerne as me lest
(base) Ye certes wyf quod he I holde it best
(base) Kys me quod she we be no lenger wrothe
(base) For by my trouthe I wol be to yow bothe
(base) This is to seyn ye bothe fair and good
(base) I pray to god that I mote steruen wood
(base) But I to yow be also good and trewe
(base) As euere was wyf syn that the world was newe
(base) And but I be to morn as fair to sene
(base) As any lady Emperice or Queene
(base) That is bitwix the Est and eek the West
(base) Do with my lyf and deth right as yow lest
(base) And so they slepte tyl it was morow gray
(base) And then she sayd when it was day
(base) Cast vp the Curtyn looke how that it is
(base) And whan the knyght say verraily al this
(base) That she so fair was and so yong ther to
(base) For ioye he hente hire in his armes two
(base) His herte bathed in a bath of blisse
(base) A thousand tyme a rewe he gan hir kisse
(base) And she obeyed hym in euery thyng
(base) That myghte do hym plesance or likyng
(base) And thus they lyue vnto hir lyues ende
(base) In parfit ioye and Ihu crist vs sende
(base) Housbondes meke yonge and fressh a bedde
(base) And grace touerbyde hem that we wedde
(base) And eek I praye Ihu shorte hir lyues
(base) That noght wol be gouerned by hir wyues
(base) And olde and angry nygardes of dispence
(base) God sende hem soone verray pestilence

div.l: (base) ¶ The prologe of the Freres tale
(base) Et incipit Prologus Freris
(base) This worthy lymytour/ this noble frere
(base) He made alwey / a manere louryng cheere
(base) Vpon the Somnour/ but for honestee
(base) No vileyns word / as yet to hym spak he
(base) But at the laste / he seyde vnto the wyf
(base) ¶ Dame quod he god yeue yow right good lyf
(base) Ye han heer touched / al so mote I thee
(base) In scole matere / greet difficultee
(base) Ye han seyd muche thyng right wel I seye
(base) But dame / here as we ryden by the weye
(base) Vs nedeth nat to speken / but of game
(base) And lete auctoritees / on goddes name
(base) To prechyng and to scole of clergye
(base) But if it like / to this compaignye
(base) I wol yow / of a Somnour telle a game
(base) Pardee / ye may wel knowe by the name
(base) That of a Somnour / may no good be sayd
(base) I praye / that noon of yow / be ypayd
(base) A somnour / is a rennere vp and doun
(base) With mandementz / for fornicacioun
(base) And is ybet at euery townes ende
(base) ¶ Oure hoost tho spak / a sire ye sholde be hende
(base) And curteys / as a man of youre estaat
(base) In compaignye / we wol no debaat
(base) Telleth youre tale / and lat the Somnour be
(base) ¶ Nay quod the Somnour / lat hym seye to me
(base) What so hym list whan it comth to my lot
(base) By god / I shal hym quyten euery grot
(base) I shal hym telle / which a gret honour
(base) It is / to be a flaterynge lymytour
(base) And of / many another manere cryme
(base) Which nedeth nat rehercen / for this tyme
(base) And his office / I shal hym telle ywys
(base) ¶ Oure hoost answerde / pees namoore of this
(base) And after this / he seyde vnto the frere
(base) Tel forth youre tale / leeue maister deere

body.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

div.l: (base) ¶ And bigynneth his tale
(base) Whilom / ther was dwellynge in my contree
(base) An Erchedekne / a man of hy degree
(base) That boldely / dide execucioun
(base) In punysshynge of Fornicacioun
(base) Of wicchecraft and eek of Bawderye
(base) Of diffamacioun / and auoutrye
(base) Of chirche Reues / and of testamentz
(base) Of contractes / and eek of lakke of sacramentz
(base) And eek of many anoþer cryme
(base) Which neediþ not to reherse at þis tyme
(base) Of vsure / and of Symonye also
(base) But certes / lecchours / dide he grettest wo
(base) They sholde syngen if that they were hent
(base) And smale tytheres were foule yschent
(base) If any persoun / wold vpon hem pleyne
(base) Ther myghte asterte hym no pecunial peyne
(base) For smale tithes and for smal offryng
(base) He made the peple ful pitusly to syng
(base) For er the bysschop caght hem with hys hooc
(base) They were in the erchdeknys book /
(base) And thanne had he thurgh hys Iurisdiccion
(base) Power to do on hem correccion
(base) He hadde a Somnour / redy to his hond
(base) A slyer boy / nas noon in Engelond
(base) For subtilly / he hadde his espiaille
(base) That taughte hym / wher hym myghte auaille
(base) He koude spare / of lecchours / oon or two
(base) To techen hym / to foure and twenty mo
(base) For theigh this Somnour / wood were as an hare
(base) To telle his harlotrye / I wol nat spare
(base) For we been / out of his correccioun
(base) They han of vs / no Iurisdiccioun
(base) Ne neuere shullen / terme of hir lyues
(base) ¶ Peter / so been wommen of the Styves
(base) Quod the Somnour / yput out of my cure
(base) ¶ Pees with myschaunce / and with mysauenture
(base) Thus seyde oure hoost / and lat hym telle his tale
(base) Now telleth forth / thogh that the Somnour gale
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne spareth nat myn owene mayster deere
(base) ¶ This false theef this Somnour / quod the frere
(base) Hadde alwey / baudes redy to his hond
(base) As any hauk to lure in Engelond
(base) That tolde hym / al the secree that they knewe
(base) For hire aqueyntance / was nat come of newe
(base) They weren / hise Approwours pryuely
(base) He took hymself / a greet profit ther by
(base) His maister knew nat alwey / what he wan
(base) Withouten mandement a lewed man
(base) He koude somne / on peyne of cristes curs
(base) And they were glade / for to fille his purs
(base) And make hym / grete festes atte nale
(base) And right as Iudas / hadde purses smale
(base) And was a theef right swich a theef was he
(base) His maister / hadde but half his duetee
(base) He was / if I shal yeuen hym his laude
(base) A theef / and eek a somnour / and a baude
(base) He hadde eek wenches / at his retenue
(base) That wheither that sir Robert / or sire hewe
(base) Or Iakke / or Rauf or who so that it were
(base) That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
(base) Thus was the wenche and he / of oon assent
(base) And he wolde fecche / a feyned mandement
(base) And somne hem to Chapitre / bothe two
(base) And pile the man / and lete the wenche go
(base) ¶ Thanne wolde he seye / freend I shal for thy sake
(base) Do stryke hire / out of oure lettres blake
(base) Thee thar namoore / as in this cas trauaille
(base) I am thy freend / ther I thee may auaille
(base) Certeyn / he knew of bryberyes mo
(base) Than possible is / to telle in yeres two
(base) For in this world / nys dogge for the bowe
(base) That kan an hurt deer / from an hool knowe
(base) Bet than this somnour / knew a sly lecchour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Or an Auouter / or a paramour
(base) And for that was / the fruyt of al his rente
(base) Therfore on it / he sette al his entente
(base) ¶ And so bifel / that ones on a day
(base) This Somnour / euere waityng on his pray
(base) For to somne an old wydewe / a Ribibe
(base) Feynynge a cause / for he wolde brybe
(base) Happed / that he say / bifore hym ryde
(base) And saw be fore hym a man ride
(base) A gay yeman / vnder a Forest syde
(base) A bowe he bar / and arwes brighte and kene
(base) He hadde vpon / a courtepy of grene
(base) An hat vpon his heed / with frenges blake
(base) ¶ Sire quod this Somnour / hayl / and wel atake
(base) ¶ Wel come quod he / and euery good felawe
(base) Where ridestow / vnder this grene shawe
(base) Seyde this yeman / wiltow fer to day
(base) ¶ This Somnour hym answerde / and seyde nay
(base) Here faste by quod he / is myn entente
(base) To ryden / for to reysen vp a rente
(base) That longeth / to my lordes duetee
(base) ¶ Artow thanne a Bailly ; / ye quod he
(base) He dorste nat for verray filthe and shame
(base) Seye that he was a Somnour / for the name
(base) ¶ Depardieux quod this yeman / deere brother
(base) Thow art a bailly / and I am another
(base) I am vnknowen / as in this contree
(base) Of thyn aqueyntance / I wolde praye thee
(base) And eek of bretherhede / if that yow leste
(base) I haue gold / and siluer in my cheste
(base) ¶ If that thee happed / to come in oure shire
(base) Al shal be thyn / right as thow wolt desire
(base) ¶ Graunt mercy quod this Somnour / by my feith
(base) Euerich in ootheres hond / his trouthe leyth
(base) For to be sworn bretheren / til they deye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And with that worde they redyn forthe hir weye
(base) ¶ This Somnour / which that was / as ful of Iangles
(base) As ful of venym / been thise waryangles
(base) And euere enqueryng vpon euery thyng
(base) Brother quod he / where is now youre dwellyng
(base) Another day / if that I sholde yow seche
(base) This yeman hym answerde / in softe speche
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / fer in the North contree
(base) Where as I hope / som tyme I shal thee see
(base) Er we departe / I shal thee so wel wisse
(base) That of myn hous / ne shaltow neuere mysse
(base) ¶ Now brother quod this Somnour / I yow preye
(base) Teche me / whil that we ryden by the weye
(base) Syn that ye been a Baillyf / as am I
(base) Som subtiltee / and tel me feithfully
(base) In myn office / how I may moost wynne
(base) And spareth nat for conscience ne synne
(base) But as my brother / tel me how do ye
(base) ¶ Now by my trouthe / brother deere / seyde he
(base) As I shal tellen thee / a feithful tale
(base) My wages been / ful streyte / and ful smale
(base) My lord is hard to me / and daungerous
(base) And myn office / is ful laborous
(base) And therfore / by extorcions I lyue
(base) For sothe I take / al that men wol me yeue
(base) Algate / by sleighte / or by violence
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / I wynne al my dispence
(base) I kan no bettre tellen / feithfully
(base) ¶ Now certes quod this Somnour / so fare I
(base) I spare nat to taken / god it woot
(base) But it be to heuy / or to hoot
(base) What I may gete / in conseil priuely
(base) No manere conscience / of that haue I
(base) Nere myn extorcioun / I myghte nat lyuen
(base) Ne of swiche Iapes / wol I nat be shryuen
(base) Stomak ne Conscience / ne knowe I noon
(base) I sherewe / thise Shryftesfadres euerychon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Wel be we met by god / and by seint Iame
(base) But leeue brother / tel me thanne thy name
(base) Quod this Somnour / in this mene whyle
(base) This yeman / gan a litel for to smyle
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / woltow that I thee telle
(base) I am a feend / my dwellyng is in helle
(base) And here I ryde / aboute my purchasyng
(base) To wite / wher men wolde yeue me any thyng
(base) My purchas / is theffect of al my rente
(base) Looke how thow rydest for the same entente
(base) To wynne good / thow rekkest neuere how
(base) Right so fare I / for ryde wold I now
(base) Vnto the worldes ende / for a preye
(base) ¶ A quod this Somnour / benedicite what sey ye
(base) I wende / ye were a yeman trewely
(base) Ye han a mannes shap / as wel as I
(base) Han ye a figure thanne / determynat
(base) In helle ther ye been / in youre estat
(base) ¶ Nay certeynly quod he / ther haue we noon
(base) But whan vs liketh / we kan take vs oon
(base) Or ellis make yow seme / we ben shape
(base) Som tyme / lyk a man / or lyk an Ape
(base) Or lyk an Aungel / kan I ryde or go
(base) It is no wonder thyng theigh it be so
(base) A lousy Iogelour / kan deceyue thee
(base) And pardee yet kan I / moore craft than he
(base) ¶ Whi quod this Somnour / ryde ye thanne or goon
(base) In sondry shap / and nat alwey in oon
(base) ¶ For we quod he / wol vs swiche formes make
(base) As moost able is / oure preyes for to take
(base) ¶ What maketh yow / to han al this labour
(base) ¶ Ful many a cause / leue sire Somnour
(base) Seyde this feend / but alle thyng hath tyme
(base) The day is short / and it is passed pryme
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And yet ne wan I no thyng in this day
(base) I wol entende / to wynnyng if I may
(base) And nat entende / oure wittes to declare
(base) For brother myn / thy wit is al to bare
(base) To vnderstonde / althogh I tolde hem thee
(base) But for thow axest why labouren we
(base) For som tyme / we been goddes Instrumentz
(base) And meenes / to doon his comandementz
(base) Whan that hym list / vpon his creatures
(base) In diuers art and in diuerse figures
(base) Withouten hym / we han no myght certayn
(base) If that hym lyst to stonde ther agayn
(base) And som tyme / at oure preyere / han we leue
(base) Oonly the body / and nat the soule greue
(base) Witnesse on Iob / whom that we diden wo
(base) And som tyme / han we myght of bothe two
(base) This is to seyn / of soule and body eke
(base) And som tyme / be we suffred for to seke
(base) Vpon a man / and do his soule vnreste
(base) And nat his body / and al is for the beste
(base) Whan he with standeth / oure temptacioun
(base) It is / a cause / of his sauacioun
(base) Al be it that it was / nat oure entente
(base) He sholde be sauf but that we wolde hym hente
(base) He shold be saaf by goddis Iugement
(base) And somtyme / be we seruant vnto man
(base) As to the Erchebisshop / Seint Dunstan
(base) And to the Apostles / seruant eek was I
(base) ¶ Yet tel me / quod the Somnour feithfully
(base) Make ye yow newe bodyes / thus alway
(base) Of Elementz / the feend answerde nay
(base) Som tyme we feyne / and som tyme we aryse
(base) With dede bodyes / in ful sondry wyse
(base) And speke as renably / and faire and wel
(base) As to the Phitonissa / dide Samuel
(base) And yet wol som men seye / it was nat he
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I do no fors / of youre dyuynytee
(base) But o thyng warne I thee / I wol nat Iape
(base) Thow wolt algates wite / how we be shape
(base) Thow shalt her afterwardes / my brother deere
(base) Come there / thee nedeth nat of me to lere
(base) For thow shalt by thyn owene experience
(base) Konne in a chayer / rede of this sentence
(base) Bet than Virgile / whil he was on lyue
(base) Or Dant also / now lat vs ryde blyue
(base) Or daūnt also whils he was on lyue
(base) For I wol holde / compaignye with thee
(base) Til it be so / that thow forsake me
(base) ¶ Nay quod this Somnour / that shal nat bityde
(base) I am a yeman / knowen is ful wyde
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / as in this cas
(base) For theigh thow were / the deuel Sathanas
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / to thee my brother
(base) As I am sworn / and ech of vs til oother
(base) For to be trewe brother / in this cas
(base) And bothe we goon / abouten oure purchas
(base) Taak thow thy part what that men wol thee yeue
(base) And I shal myn / thus may we bothe lyue
(base) And if that any of vs / haue moore than oother
(base) Lat hym be trewe / and parte it with his brother
(base) ¶ I graunte quod the deuel / by my fey
(base) And with that word / they ryden forth hir wey
(base) And right at the entryng of the townes ende
(base) To which this Somnour / shoop hym for to wende
(base) They saye a Cart that charged was with hey
(base) Which that a Cartere / droof forth in his wey
(base) Deep was the wey / for which the Carte stood
(base) This Cartere smoot and cryde as he were wood
(base) Hayt Brok hayt Scot what spare ye for the stones
(base) The feend quod he / yow fecche body and bones
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The deuel haue al / bothe hors and Cart and hey
(base) ¶ This Somnour seyde / heer shul we han a pley
(base) And neer the feend he drogh / as noght ne were
(base) Ful pryuely / and rowned in his ere
(base) Herkne my brother / herkne by thy feith
(base) Herestow nat how that the Cartere seith
(base) Hent it anon / for he hath yeue it thee
(base) Bothe hey / and Cart and eek his caples thre
(base) ¶ Nay quod the deuel / god woot neuer a del
(base) It is nat his entente / trust thow me wel
(base) Axe hym thy self if thow nat trowest me
(base) Or ellys stynt a while / and thow shalt se
(base) ¶ This Cartere / taketh his hors vpon the croupe
(base) And they bigonne / drawen and to stoupe
(base) Heyt now quod he / ther Ihu crist yow blesse
(base) And al his handes werk bothe moore and lesse
(base) That was wel twight myn owene lyard boy
(base) I pray god saue thee / and Seint loy
(base) Now is my Cart out of the slow pardee
(base) ¶ Lo brother quod the feend / what tolde I thee
(base) Heere may ye se / myn owene deere brother
(base) The Carl spak o thyng but he thoghte another
(base) Lat vs go forth / abouten oure viage
(base) Heere wynne I no thyng vpon cariage
(base) ¶ Whan that they coomen / som what out of towne
(base) This Somnour / to his brother gan to rowne
(base) Brother quod he / here woneth an old rebekke
(base) That hadde almoost as leef to lese hir nekke
(base) As for to yeue a peny / of hir good
(base) I wol han twelue pens / thogh that she be wood
(base) Or I wol somne hire / vnto oure office
(base) And yet god woot of hire knowe I no vice
(base) But for thow canst nat as in this contree
(base) Wynne thy cost taak heer ensample of me
(base) This Somnour / clappeth at the wydwes gate
(base) Com out quod he / thow olde viritrate
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I trowe thow hast som frere / or preest with thee
(base) ¶ Who clappeth seyde this wyf / benedicitee
(base) God saue yow sire / what is youre swete wille
(base) ¶ I haue quod he / of somonce a bille
(base) Vp peyne of cursyng looke that thow be
(base) To morn / bifore the Erchedeknes knee
(base) Tanswere to the court of certeyn thynges
(base) ¶ Now lord quod she / crist Ihu kyng of kynges
(base) So wisly helpe me / as I ne may
(base) I haue been syk and that ful many a day
(base) I may nat go so fer quod she / ne ryde
(base) But I be deed / so priketh it in my syde
(base) May I nat axe a libel / sire Somnour
(base) And answere there / by my procutour
(base) To swich thyng as men wole opposen me
(base) ¶ Yis quod this Somnour / pay anon lat see
(base) Twelf pens to me / and I wol thee acquyte
(base) I shal no profit han ther by / but lyte
(base) ¶ My Maister hath the profit / and nat I
(base) Com of / and lat me ryden hastily
(base) Yif me .twelue. pens / I may no lenger tarye
(base) ¶ Twelf pens quod she / now lady Seinte Marie
(base) So wisly help me god / out of care and synne
(base) This wyde world / thogh that I sholde wynne
(base) Ne haue I nat twelue pens / with Inne myn hoold
(base) Ye knowen wel / that I am poure and oold
(base) Kythe youre almesse / on me poure wrecche
(base) ¶ Nay thanne quod he / the foule feend me fecche
(base) If I thexcuse / theigh thow shul be spilt
(base) ¶ Allas quod she / god woot I haue no gilt
(base) ¶ Pay me quod he / or by the swete Seinte Anne
(base) As I wol bere awey / thy newe panne
(base) For dette / which thow owest me of oold
(base) Whan that thow madest / thyn housbonde cokewold
(base) I payde at hom / for thy correccioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Thow lyxt quod she / by my sauacioun
(base) Ne was I neuere er now / wydwe ne wyf
(base) Somoned vnto youre court in al my lyf /
(base) Ne neuere I nas / but of my body trewe
(base) Vnto the deuel / blak and row of hewe

div.l: The prologue of thþe clerke of Oxenford
xIr Clerke of Oxenford oure oste sayde
Ye ryde as stylle and coy as a mayde
Were newe spoused sittyng at þe borde
This day ne herde y of youre mouth a word
I trowe ye study aboute some sophyme
But Salamon seith all thyng hath tyme
For goddꝭes sake as be ye of Bettꝰer chere
Yit is no tyme now to study here
Tel vs som mury tale by youre fay
For when a man ys entred in to play
He mote nedes to þat play assent
But pꝰercheth not as Freres don in lente
To make us for oure old synnꝭes to wepe
Ne that thy tale make us to slepe
Tel us som mery thyng of auentures
Youre termes youre coloures and Figures
Kepeth hem in store tyl so be ye hem endyte
High style as whan men to kyngꝭes endyte
Speketh so playn at this tyme y you paray
That we may vnderstond what ye say
This worthy clerk benygnely answerd
Oste quoth he y am vnder youre yerde
Ye haue as now of us þe govꝰernaunce
And thþꝰerfor wol y doo you obeysaunce
As Ferr as Resou wel hardely
I wol yow tel a tale which þat y
Lerned at padow of a worthi clerk
As proveth by his wordes ⁊ werke
Fraunceys petrake þe laureat poete
Highte þis clerk whoso retoryk seeke
And now wol y procede to my mater
This ys my tale which ye shal her
The clerk of Oxenford tale
there ys ryghte at þe west syde of Itayle
Doun at þe rote of wesþylus þe olde
A lusty playn haboundant of vytayle
Wher many a toure and town thþu may byhold
That founded wer in tyme of Fadres olde
And many a nother delytabal sighte
And salus that noble contrꝰer hight
x marquys sometyme lord was of þtat lond
As were his worthi eldres hym byfore
And obeysant wer en ay redy to his hond
Al his leges both lesse and more
Thus in delyte he lyueth and hath do yore
Byloued and dredde by fauoꝰer of Fortune
Both of his lordes and of his commune
ther with he was no to speke as of lynage
The gentilest Borne as of lumbardy
A Fayre ꝑpersone strong and yonge of age
And ful of honoure and of curtesye
Dyscret y nowh his contre for to gye
Saue in some thyngꝭes he was to Blame
And Waltꝰer was this yong lordꝭes name
y Blame hym thus that he considreth nougte
In tyme comyng what hym myghte betyde
But on his lust pꝰersent was al his thougte
Wel nygh alle othur cures leet he slyde
But for to hawke and hunte on euꝰery syde
And eek he nold and þat was worst of al
Wedde no wyfe for nouȝt þat myȝte byfal
hys pepul hym bysecheth to take þe yok
Of souꝰerynte nougt of servyse
Which men clepe spowsayle or wedlok
And thenke lord amonge yorur thoghtes wyse
While now ys tyme taketh this devyse
For thouȝe we slepe renne wake or ryde
And flydeth þe tyme it wol no man abyde
and thouȝe youre grene youthe floryssth as yette
In crepeth age as stylle as any stone
And deth manaseth euꝰery age and smyte
In yche astate for þer askapeth none
That also certeyn as we knowe euꝰery chone
That we shal þat vncerteyn we al
Ben of that day þat doth on vs shal falle
delyueth us oute of this besy drede
And taketh a wyf for hiȝe goddꝭes sake
For yf so byfel as godde forbede
That thurow your deth your lynage schulde slake
And wo a straunge successour shuld take
Youre herytage wo were vs on lyue
Wherfore we paray you hastely to wyve
Her meke parayer and her pyto9us chere
Made the lorde herte to haue pyte
Ye wold not qd he myn owen pepul der
So that I neuꝰer erst thougte streyne me
I me reioysed of my lyberte
That selden tyme ys founde in maryage
Ther as was fre thynge moot ben in ꝸseruage
but nathelese y see your trewe entente
And truste vp on yorur witte and haue doon ay
Wher of my fre wylle y wol assente
To wedde me as sone as euꝰer y may
But ther as ye hau proferd me to day
To chese me a wyf y woll relese
Of þat choyse y pray yow yourꝰer profre cese
xete me allone in chesyng of my wyfe
And þat charge on my bak I wol endurꝰer
But y paray you and charge on yourꝰer lyfe
That what wyfr y take ye me ensure
To worship hir whileþ hir lyfe may dure
In worde in werke both here and euꝰery wher
As she an Empours doughtꝰer werꝰer
and furthermore swere shal ye
Ayayn my choyse shal ye neuꝰer stryue
For sythe y shal forso my lyberte
At youre requeste so euꝰer mote y thryve
Ther as my herte is sette þꝰer wol I wyue
And but ye wol assente in swich manerꝰer
Y pꝰery yow speke nomorꝰer of this materꝰer
with hertely wylle they swore and assent
To al this thyng þꝰer sayd no wight nay
Besechyng of grace er þat he wente
That he wolde graunte to hem a certeyn day
Of his spowsayle as sone as euere he may
For yette þe peple somwhat hem dredde
Lest that he no wyf wolde wedde
xE graunted hem a day swuch as hym lyste
On which he wolde be wedded sikerly
And seid he dydde al this at hir request
And with humble entent buxomly
Kneled on hur knees ful reuꝰerently
And thanked hym al and thus they ende
Of hir entente and home þey wende
and þꝰer vp on he he his ofycers
Comaundeth for the feste to puruey
And to his pꝰerue knyght9 and squyers
Such chauge as hym luste on hem ley
And they to his comaundement obey
And yche of hem doth his dylygence
To douꝰer þe feste grete reuꝰerence
noghte ferrꝰer fro palys honorable
Where as the lord schop his maryage
Ther stode a thrope delytabal
In which that pore folke of that village
Hadden her beste and her herbygage
And of her labourꝰer tokee her sustenunce
After þat þe Erthe yafe hem habundauns
Amonge this pore folke dwelleth a man
Which þat was olde and porest of hem al
But hige god somtyme send kan
His grace to a lytel Oxe stal
Ianycle me of the thrope hym cal
A doughtꝰer he hadde feyre y nouh to sight
And grysel þis yong mayd hiȝte
But for to speke of vertues and bewte
Than was she one þe fayrest vnder sonne
Wel porely fostred was she
No likerousnesse was on her herte y ronne
Wel ofter of þe wel þan of the tonne
She dronke and for she wold vertu plese
She knew wel labour but noon ydelnesse
xut thouȝe this mayde were tender of age
Yette in the brest of hir virgynyte
Ther was enclosed rype and sadde corage
And in gret reuꝰerence and grete Charyte
Hir olde pore fader fostred she
A fewe shepe on the feld she kepte
She nolde be ydel til she slepte
up on Grysel þe pore creaturꝰer
Wol ofte hath þis lord sette his yȝe
As he on huntyng rode ꝑperauenturꝰer
And when hit fel þat he hir myȝt aspye
He not with wantown lokyng of soly
His yȝen caste on hir but in sad wyse
Vpon hir cher he wold hym ofte auyse
uOmmendyng in his hert hir wommanhed
And eke hir vertu passyng any wiȝte
Of so yong age as wel as in dede
For though þe pepul haue no gret insight
In vertu he consydreth ful right
Hur bowte and dysposed þat he wold
Hur wedde yf onꝰer he wedde schuld
the day of weddyng cam but no wyght kan
Telle what woman hit shuld be
For which mꝰeruayle wondreth many man
And saiden when þey werꝰer in pꝰeruete
Wol nat oure lord leue his uanyte
Wol he not wedde allas þe while
Whi wol he hym self and vs thus bigyle
xut nathelese hath this lord lete make
Of Gemes set in gold and in azurꝰer
Broches and rynge for gryssels sake
And of hur clothyng toke he þe mesurꝰer
Of a mayd lyke to her staturꝰer
And eke of hur Ornament9 alle
That to such a weddyng schuld falle
the tyme of vndren in þe same day
Approched þat his weddyng schuld be
And al the paleys was sette in aray
Both hal and chambres in her degre
Houses of Offyce stuffed with grete plente
Ther may men seen deyntes of vitayle
That may be founde as ferrꝰer as lasteth Itayle
this ryal maryage ryally arayed
Lordes and her ladyes in her company
The which to þe feste were prayed
And of his retenue þe Bachelery
Whith mande a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village of which y told
In this array þe right wey þey hold
gRiseld god wote of this ful Innocent
That for hir was schape al this aray
To fetche watꝰer at a wel ys wente
And come home as sone as sche may
For wel sche herd sey þat ylk day
The markes schuld and yf sche myghte
Sche wold fayn see some of that sight
sche thouȝte sche wold with oþꝰer maydens stond
That ben my felow9 in ourꝰer dorꝰer and see
These lordys and ladys þꝰerforꝰer wol y fonde
To done at home as sone as hit may be
The labourꝰer which longeth vn to me
And þan may y hit at leysourꝰer byhold
Yf sche þis wey to the castel hold
And as sche wold ouꝰer þe þelde goon
The marquys kam ageyn hur to calle
And sche sette doun her watꝰer potte anone
Bisyde the thresthold of the oxestal
And doun upon her knees she gan to falle
And with sadde countenance kneled stylle
Til sche had herd þe lord9 wylle
this noble marquys spake vn to mayd
Wel sobrely and seid in this manerꝰer
Wherꝰer ys yourꝰer fader Gryseld he sayd
And sche with reuꝰerence and mete??? chere
Answerd lord he is al redy herꝰer
And ??? she goth with oute lengꝰer lette
And to hur lord hur fadur sche sette
hE by the hond þan toke þis old man
And seyd þus when he hym had asyde
Ianycle y ne may ne kan
Lengꝰer þe plesance of myn herte hyde
Yf þat þu vouchesafe what so betyde
Thy doghtꝰer wol y take or þat y wende
As for my wyfe to oure lyues ende
Thow louest me y wote wel certeyn
And art my feithful lege man y bore
And al this lyketh me y dar wel seyn
yf hit lyke the and specyally þꝰerforꝰer
Tel me that poynte that y haue seid to fore
yf that þu wolt vn to þis purpose drawe
To take me as for thi sonne in lawe
the sodeyn case þe man astoneyd so
That reede he waxe abassched and quakynge
He stode vnneth he sayd one word mo
But onely this quoth he lord my wyllyng
Ys as ye wol nought ageyn yourꝰer lykyng
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so derꝰer
Right as ye luste gouꝰerneth þis materꝰer
than wol y doo þis quoth mark9 softely
That in thy chambre y thow and sche
Haue a collacioun and wost why
For y wol aske hur yf hur wyl be
To be my wyfe and rule hur aftꝰer me
And al þis sche schal doo in thi pꝰersence
I wol not speke oute of thi audyence
and in this chambre while they werꝰer aboute
Her tretyse which ys schal aftꝰer herꝰer
The pepul cam in to the house with oute
And wondreth hem in honest manerꝰer
And tentyfly sche kept hur fader derꝰer
But outerly Grisil wondre myght
For nouꝰer ere sawh sche suich a sight
no wonder was thogh sche werꝰer astonyed
To see so grete a geste com in to that plase
Sche was nouꝰer to such gest9 wonned
For which sche looketh with pale fase
But schortely fro this matere to passe
These were the wordes that þe lord saide
To this benygue veray feythful mayde
grisil he seid y wol ye vnderstond
Hit liketh un to youre fader and to me
That y you wedde schal and eke hit may stonde
As y suppose þat ye wol hit so be
But this demaunde y aske furst quoth sche
That sith hit schal be doo in hasty wyse
Wol ye assent or ell yow auyse
y say thus be ye Redy with gode herte
To al my luste þtat y frely may
As me best thenketh doo yow lawh or smerte
And ye neuꝰer to grucche nyȝte ne day
And eke when y say ye say not nay
Neyther by worde ne froward contenance
Swere this and herꝰer y swerꝰer oure allyānnnc̄etce
wondryng on this word quakyng for drede
Sche seid vndigne or vnworthy
Am y to that ye me lede
But right as ye wol lord so wol y
And swere that neuꝰer wyllyngly
In word ne dede y wol you disobeye
For to be dede þouȝe me werꝰer loth to dye
this ys y nowh myn own grysel qd he
And forth he goth with a sober cherꝰer
Oute of þe chimmbrꝰer dorꝰer and aftꝰer cometh sche
And to the pepul he seid on this mannerꝰer
This is my wyfe that standeth herꝰer
Honowreth and loueth hur y yow paray
Whoso loueth me þꝰer is no morꝰer to say
and for no thynge of hur olde gerꝰer
Sche schoud bryng to his house he hadbadhadbad
That ladyes schuld spoyle hirꝰer right therꝰer
Of which þe ladyes werꝰer nothyng gladde
To handle her clothes in which sche was cladde
But nathelese this mayden brighte of hewe
Fro fote to hede clothed haue they al newe
hur heres haue they kembed þtat lay vntressed
Wel redely with hur fyngres smale
And a croun on hir hede haue they dressed
And sette hit ful of owches grete and smale
Of hur aray what schuld y make a tale
Vnneth the pepul hur knew for hur fayrnesse
Whan sche tranformed was in such rychesse
this ???Marcus hath hur spoused wtith a rynge
And after ryally hath hur sette
Vpon a white palfrayh wel ammblynge
And to his paleys or he lengꝰer lette
With ioyful þat he had and mette
Convoieth hur and and thus þe day they spende
In Reuel tyl þe day gan descende
And shortely forth this tale for to trace
Of this lady I sey this marguyses
God hath sent such fauorur of his grace
That hit semeth not as by lykenesse
That sche was born and fedde in Rudenesse
As in a cote or in an oxe stal
But noryssched in an Empours halle
to euꝰery wyght ys sche woxen so dere
And worschipful þat folk þꝰer sche was borꝰer
And fro hur byrth knewe hur fro yerꝰer to yerꝰer
Vnneth trouth durst þey haue swore
That to Ianicle of which y spake byfore
Sche doghtꝰer ne were for as by coniecturꝰer
Hem thoughtꝰer sche was a nother creaturꝰer
For that euꝰer vertuous was sche
Sche was encressed in such excellence
Of thewes sette in hiȝe bountee
And so discreet and fayre of eloquence
So benygne and digne of Reuꝰerence
And kowde þe pepul hert9 so enbrase
That evꝰery hur louede þtat loked in her fase
nought onely of Salus in the town
Publyssched was the bounte of hur name
And eke bysyde in many a regyoun
Yf one sayd wel a nother seid þe same
So spradde of hur bounte the fame
That men and women both yong and old
Comen to Salus on hur to byholde
thus Marcus wedded lowly nay but ryally
With fortune and with honeste
In goddes pees lyueth wel esyly
At hom and outward grace y now had he
And for he sawh vnder lowe degre
Was ofte vertu y hydde þe ??? deynysch he hy held
A prudent man and þtat is seyn ful seld
nought longe tyme after this Gryseld
Was wedded sche a doghtꝰer had y bore
Al had sche leuer haue had a knaue chylde
Glad was this Marcus and his folk þꝰerfore
For thoyȝ a mayd chylde com al byfore
Sche may a knaue chyld aftꝰeratteyne
By lyklyhede sith sche ys nouȝt bareyn
therfore as hit falleth tymes moo
When this chyld hath souked but a throwe
This Marcus in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf hur sadnes to knowe
That he ne myght fro his hert throwe
This mꝰeruelouse desyre his wyf to asay
Nethelesse he thuȝte hur to affraye
He had asayed hur ynowh to fore
And fonde hur eurery goodlynes what nedeth hit
Hur for to torment and alwey more and more
Thouȝe þat som men pꝰeryse hit for a sotel wytte
But as for me y sey that euel hit sytte
To assay a wyfe whan hit is no nede
And putte hur in angwyssch or drede
for which this Marcus thouȝte in this manerꝰer
A nyȝte alone þꝰer as sche lay
With sterne fase and truel cherꝰer
And said to Gryseld quoth he þat day
That y yow toke of youre pore aray
And putte yow in astatte of hiȝe noblesse
Ye haue not yette forgeten as y gesse
I say Grysild this pꝰersent dignyte
In which y haue putte yow as y trowe
Maketh yow not forȝeteful for to be
That y yow toke in pore astatte ful lowe
For any thyng ye mote yorur self knowe
Taketh hede of euꝰery word þat y yow sey
There is no wyght hereth this but we tweye
ye wote your self wel how ye came here
In to this house hit is not long a goo
And thouȝe to me ye be lefe and dere
