div.l: The prolog of þe doctorur of phisik
when that this yeman his tale ended had
Of this false chanoun which he ended had
Oure oste gan to sey tuly and certeyn
This preste was bygyled sothely to seyn
He wenynge for to be a philosopher
Tyll he right no gold lefte in his cofer
And sothely this preste had a lyther Iape
This cursed chanou putte in his hode an ape
But all this wor assen as now
Sir doctorur of phisyk y pray yow
Tell us a tale of som honest mater
Hit schall be don yf ye woll hit her
¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
A knyght that called was Virginius
Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
No children hadde he mo in al his lif
Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
Abouen euery wight that man may see
For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
Yformed hire in so greet excellence
As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
If they presumeden me to countrefete
For he that is the formere principal
Hath maked me his vicaire general
To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
My lord and I been ful of oon acord
I made hire to the worship of my lord
So do I alle myne othere creatures
What colour that they han or what figures
Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
In which that nature hadde swich delit
For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
She peynted hath this noble creature
Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
And if that excellent was hir beautee
A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
In hire ne lakked no condicioun
That is to preyse as by discrecioun
As wel in goost as body chaast was she
For which she floured in virginitee
With all humilitee and abstinence
With all atemperance and pacience
With mesure eek of beryng and array
Discreet she was in answeryng alway
Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
No countrefeted termes hadde she
To seme wys but after hir degree
She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
Where likly was to treten of folye
As is at festes reuels and at daunces
That been occasions of daliaunces
Swich thyng maken children for to be
To soone rype and boold as men may se
Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
For al to soone may they lerne loore
Which afterward may greve þeim sore
Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
That they perisse for I dar wel seye
If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
For I moot turne agayn to my matere
¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
As in a book euery good word or dede
That longeth to a mayden vertuous
She was so prudent and so bounteuous
For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
That loued vertu saue enuye allone
That sory is of oother mennes wele
And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
The doctor maketh this discripcioun
This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
Toward a temple with hir moder deere
As is of yonge maydens the manere
¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
That gouernour was of that Regioun
And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
This mayde shal by myn for any man
Anon the feend in to his herte ran
And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
For certes by no force ne by no meede
Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
For she was strong of freendes and eek she
Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
As for to make hire with hir body synne
For which by greet deliberacioun
He sente after a cherl was in the town
Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
In secree wise and made hym to ensure
He sholde telle it to no creature
And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
Whan that assented was this cursed reed
Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
Fro point to point how that his lecherie
Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
As ye shul heere it after openly
¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
This false Iuge that highte Apius
So was his name for this is no fable
But knowen for historial thyng notable
The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
To hasten his delit al that he may
And so bifel soone after on a day
This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
As we fine writen in olde storie
As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
And right anon was rad this cursed bille
The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
How that a knyght called Virginius
Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
My seruant which that is my thral by right
Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
But hastily er he his tale tolde
And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
Ne here a word moore of Virginius
But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
And with a face deed as asshen colde
Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
O deere doghter endere of my lyf
Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
O doghter which that art my laste wo
And in my lyf my laste ioye also
O gemme of chastitee in pacience
Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
Allas that euere Apius thee say
Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
And seyde goode fader shal I dye
Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas

This lytel childe as he com to and fro

sEy now somwhat syth oþꝰer folk haue seyd

And y woll yow tell verament

All of a knyȝte fayre ⁊ gent

His name was ꝸser Thopas

in toun

Nett9 of gold threde had he gret plente
To Fysschen in Tyber whan hym luste to play
Hys lustes were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his Frend wold hy obey
HE Rome brent for his delycasye
The Senatour9 he slough on a day
To here where þat men wold wepe or crye
And slowh his broder and by his sustꝰer lay
Hys moder made he in pytous Aray
For he hur wombe slytte to byhold
Where he conseyved was so weylaway
That he so lytel of his moder told
No tere oute of his yȝen for that sight
Ne cam but sayd a fayre woman ys sche
Grete wonder ys that he kowde or myght
Be domysman of hur dede bewte
The wyne to brynge comaunded he
He dronke anone and none oþꝰer wo made
Whan myght is ioyned vn to cruelte
Allas to depe wold þe venym wade
In youthe a Mayster had þis Emꝑperourꝰer
To tech hym lectrurꝰer and curyosyte
For of moralyte he was the flourꝰer
As in his tyme but yf bokꝭes lye
And whiles his Mayster had of hym Maystrye
He made hym so connyng and so sowple
That long tyme or Tyrannye
Or any vyce of hym durste vncowple
This Seneka of which y devyse
By cause nero had of hym such drede
For he for vyces wold hym chastyse
Dyscretely as by word and not by dede
Sirꝰer wold he seyne an Emꝑperorur mot nede
Be vertuous and hate Tyrannye
For which in a bath he made hy to blede
On both his Armes tyll he most dye
This Nero had eke A custumaūns
In youth ayeyn his mayster to Aryse
Which hym thouȝte After a greuaūns
Therfore he made hy dye in such wyse
But natheles this Seneke the wyse
Chese in a bathe to dye in this manere
Rather than mo oþꝰer turmentyes
And thus hath Nero slayn his mayster dere
Now felle it so that fortune lyste no lenger
The hiȝe piride of Nero to cheryssh
For thouȝe he were strong yet ys sche more streng
Sche thought thus by god y am to nyse
To sette aman that is fullfylled of vyse
In hiȝe degre and Emꝑperourꝰer hym calle
By god oute of his sete y woll hy tryse
Whan he leste weneth sonnest schall he falle
The peple Rose up on hy on a nyght
For his defaute And when he hit aspyed
Oute at þe dores anone he hath hy hyȝed
Allone and therꝰer he wende to haue ben allyed
He knokked faste and ay the more he cryed
The faster schutten they þe dores alle
Tho wyste he well he had hyself myssegyed
And went his wey no lengꝰer wold he calle
The peple ciried and Rumbled up and doun
That with his eres herd he how þey seyd
Wherꝰer is this false traytourꝰer this Neroun
For feerꝰer almost oute of his wytte he brayde
And to his godd9 pytously he sayd
For socour but it myght not bytyde
For drde of this hym thought þat he dyed
And rane in to a gardyn hym self to hyde
And in this fond he Churles twey
And setten by a fyrꝰer ful grete and red
And to þese churles twey he gan to prey
To slene hym and to gardeyn of his hed
That to his Body when he werꝰer dede
Were no despyte y doo as for his defame
Hym self he slowh he kowde no bettꝰer rede
Of which fortune lowh and made game
Was neuꝰer capteyn vnder a kynge
That regnes mo putte in subieccioun
Ne strenger was in the feld of all thynge
As in his tyme ne grettꝰer of Renoun
Ne more pompous in hiȝe pꝰersumpcyoun
Than Olyferne which fortune ay kest
So lykoursly and ladde hym up and doun
Tyll that his hede was of or that he wyste
Not onely that this world had of hym Awe
For lusynge of Richesse and of lyberte
But he made euꝰery man reneye his lay
None oþꝰer god schuld honoured be
For Nabugodonosore was lord quoth he
Ayeynst his hest no man dar trespasse
Save in Betulya a stronge Cyte
Wherꝰer Elyachym a pꝰerste was of that plase
But take kepe of the deth of Olyferne
Amydde his oste he dronke lay on a nyȝte
With in his tente large as ys a berne
And yette for all his pompe and all his piride myȝte
Iudyth a woman as he lay upryght
Slepynge his hede of smote and fro his tente
Full prevely sche stale from euꝰery wyght
What nedeth hit of kynge Anteocheus
To telle his hiȝe and ryall mageste
Hys hiȝe piride his werkꝭes venymous
For such a noþꝰer nas none but he
Redeth which he was in Machabe
And redeth the proude wordes that he sayd
And why he felle fro his prosꝑperyte
And in an halle how wrecched he dyed
FOrtune hym had so enhaunsed in piride
That verayly he wende he myght enteyne
Vn to the sterres on euꝰery side
And in a Balaūns to wey þe mounteyn
And all the flodes of the see restreyn
And godd9 pepull had he most in hate
Hem wold he slee in turment and in peyn
Wenyng that god ne myght his piride abate
ANd for that Nychamoure and Tymothe
With Iewes were venquyssed myȝtely
Vn to the Iewes such an hate had he
That he had greythed his chare full hastyly
And swore and sayd full spytously
Vn to Ierlm wold he eftesone
To wreke his Ire on hit full cruelly
But of his purpose was he lette full sone
God for his manace hym so sore smote
With invysible woundes ay incurable
That in his guttes carfe so aboute
That his peynes werꝰer inportable
And certeynly the wrecche was vnresonable
For many mann9 guttes dyd he peyne
But fro his purpose cursed and dampnable
For all his smerte he nold hym restreyne
But bad anone apꝑperayle his oste
And sodeynly or he of it was warꝰer
God daunted all his piride and his boste
For he so sore fell oute of his chare
That hurte his lymes and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myȝte go ne ryde
But in a chayer men aboute hy bare
All forbrused both bak and syde
The wreche of god hym smot so spytously
That in his body wykked wormes crepe
And þꝰer with all he stonke so orrybly
That none of alle his meyne that hym kepte
Wheþꝰer þat he woke or ellez slepe
Ne myȝte not the stynke of hym Endure
In this myschef he wayled and wepte
And knewe god his lord to fore any creature
TO all his oste and to hym self also
Full fulsom was the stynke of his kareyn
No man myȝte hym bere to and fro
And in his stynk and orryble peyne
He starf full wrecchedly in a mounteyn
Thus hath this Robbour and homycyde
That many a man made to wepe ⁊ pleyn
Such guerdon as by longe to pryde
The story of Alexaundrꝰer ys so comune
That euꝰery wyght that hath dyscressyou
Hath herd somwhat of all of his fortune
This wyde world as in conclusyoun
He wan by strenght or for his renoun
They were glad for pees vn to hy to send
The piride of man and best he leyd a doun
Where so he cam vn to the worldꝭes ende
COmparysou myȝte neuer be maked
Bytwene hym and a noþꝰer creature 9querorur
For all this world for hym hath quaked
He was of knyghthod and of Fredom flourꝰer
Fortune hym made þe Eyre of hurꝰer honourꝰer
Save wyne and women no thyng myȝte aswage
Hys hiȝe entente in armez and labourꝰer
So was he full of lovyng Corage
What pyte were hit to hy thouȝe y yow told
Of daryous and a hundred thousand mo
Of kyngꝭes pirinsez and erlez bold
Which he conquered and brought hym in to woo
I sey as ferrꝰer as men myȝte ryght ryde or goo
The world was his what schuld y more devyse
For thouȝe y wrote and told you euꝰer mo
Of his knyghthod it may not suffyse
Twelue yere he reigned as seith Machabe
Phillips sonne of Massidone was he
That furst was kyng of grece þe cuntre
O worthi gentell alexaunder quoth he
Allas þtat euꝰer schuld þu falle in such degre
Empoysened of thi folk þu werꝰer
Thi fortune in to an aas hath turned þe
And yet for the ne wepe sche neuꝰer a teere
Who schall gyffe teres or compleyn
The deth of gentelnesse and of Fraunchyse
That all þe world weld in his demeyne
And yet hym thouȝte hit myȝte not suffyse
So full was his corage of hiȝe Empryse
Allas who schall me helpe to endyte
False fortune and poysou to despyse
The which too of all this world y wyte
By wysdom manhede and by labourꝰer
Fro humblehed and fro ryall mageste
Vp rose Iulyus the noble conquerourꝰer
That all þe occydent by lond ⁊ by see
By strenght of hond or ellez by trete
And vn to Rome made hem tributary
And sethens of Rome þe Emꝑperourꝰer was he
Tyl þat fortune waxe his aduꝰersarye
O myȝty Cesar that in tessalye
Ayeynst pompeous fader thyne in lawe
That of þe oryent had all the Chyualery
As Ferrꝰer as þe day bygynneth to dawe
Thorou thi knyghthode hast hym slawe
Save a Few folk that with pompeous fledde
For which þu puttest all þe oryent in awe
Thonke Fortune that þe so well spedde
But now a lytell while y woll bywayle
This pompeous this noble gouꝰernourꝰer
Of Rome which þat fleyȝte at this batayle
I sey one of his men a fals taraytourꝰer
His hede of smote to wynne hym fauoure
Of Iulius and hym the hede brought
Allas pompeous of the Oryent conquerourꝰer
That fortune vn to such a fyn brought
TO Rome ayeyn repayreth Iulius
With his tryumphe laureat full hiȝe
But on a tyme Brutus caseus
That euꝰer had of his Astate Enuy
Full piriuely had mad conspiracy
Ayeynst þis Iullius in sotel wyse
And cast þe plase on which he schuld dye
With Boydekyns as y schall yow devyse
This Iulius to the Chapitole went
Vp on a day as he was wonte to gon
And in the Chapitoile anone hym hent
This false brutus and his false fone
Haue stykked hym with boydekyns Anone
With many a wound and þus þey let hy lye
But neuꝰer grunte he at no strok but one
Or ellez at two but yf his story lye
SO manly was this Iulius of herte
And so well loued estately honeste
That thouȝe his dedely wound9 so sore smert
His mantell ouꝰer his hepes cast he
For no man schuld see his pirivete .
And as he lay in dyeng on a traunse
And wyste verayly that ded was he
Of honeste yet had he remembraunse
Lucan to this story y recomend
And to swetou and to valerous also
That of this story wryteth word ⁊ ende
How that þese grete conquerours two
Fortune was hur Frende and aftꝰer her Foo
To man truste up on his fauorur long
But haue her in a wayte euꝰer mo
Wittenesse of all these conquerours strong
This Riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde
Of which gresus sequius sore hym dredde
Yette was he kaught amoust all his piride
And to be brent men to the fyre hym ladde
But such arayn doun fro the walkyn schadde
That slough þe fyre and made hym to eskape
But to be warr yette no grace he hadd
Tyll fortune on the galowes made hy gape
Whan he escaped was kan he not stynte
For to bygyn a newe regne ageyn
He wend well for þat fortune hym sente
Such happe þat he eskaped thorou the reyn
That of his foos he myȝte not be slayn
And such a sweven on a nyȝte he mette
Of which he was so proude ⁊ fayn
That he in vengeaunce all his hert sette
Op on a tree was he as hym thouȝte
There Iubyter hy wyssch both halse ⁊ syde
And phebus eke a fayre towayle hy brouȝte
To drye hym with and þꝰer forꝰer waxe his piride
And to his doughter þat stode hym bysyde .
Which þat he knewe in hiȝe sentence habound
He badde hur telle what it signyfyed
And sche his dreme thus expouned
The tree qd sche the galow9 is to mene
And Iubiter bytokeneth snow and reyn
And phebus with his towayle so clerꝰer
Tho ben þe sonne stremez for to sayn
Thou schall an honged be fader certeyn
Rayn schall þe wassh and sonne schall þe drye
Thus warned sche hym full platte and playn
Hys doughtꝰer þtat called was Phavye
An honged was Cresus the pꝰercous king
Hys ryall trone myȝte hym not avayle
Tregedys ys none oþꝰer manꝰer thyng
Ne kan in synnyng cry ne bywayle
But that fortune alwey woll assayle
With vnwarꝰer strok þe Reynes that ben proude
For when men trysten hur þen wol sche fayle
And kever her bryght fase wtith a cloude

l.hi: The prolog of þe Nonnes Preste ;

div.l: HOo quoth the knyght ꝸser no more of this
That ye haue seid hit ys y nowh ywysse
And mych more for lytull heuynesse
Ys right ynowh to myche folk y gesse
I sey for me hit ys grete dyssese
Where as men haue ben in welth and ese
To here of hur sodeyn falle allas
And the contarary ys ioy and gret solas
As when a man hath ben in pore astate
And clymbeth and waxeth fortunate
And there abydeth in prosꝑperite
Such thyng ys gladsom as thenketh me
And thouȝe such thyng were goodely to tell
Ye quoth oure oste by seynte poules bell
Ye sey ryȝt soth this monk clappud lowde
He spake how fortune kouꝰered with a clowde
Y not neuꝰer what and also Treiardy
Right nowe ye herd and ꝑperde no remedy
Ys for to be wayle and complayn
That þat is don and all ys a payn
As ye haue seid to here of heuynesse
Sir monk no morꝰer of this so god you blesse
Youre tale anoyeth all this Company
Such talkyng ys not worth a buttꝰer flye
For þꝰer nys noþꝰer desporte ne game
Wherforꝰer ꝸser monk dau pers by yorur name
I paray you hertely tell us somwhat elles
For syker ner þe chynglyng as hit werꝰer bell
That on yorur Brydel hangeth on euꝰery syde
By heuen kyng þtat for us all dyed
I schuld as for this falle doun for slepe
Althouȝe þe slowh had neuꝰer ben so depe
Than had yourꝰer tale be told in vayn
For certaynly as these clerkes seyn
Where as a man may haue no audynece
Nought helpeth to telle his sentence
And well y wote þe substaunce ys in me
If any thyng schall reported be
Sir say somwhat of huntyng y you paray
Nay quoth þe monk I haue no luste to play
Now lete a noþꝰer tell as y haue tolde
Then spake ourꝰer ourꝰer oste ful bolde
And seyd vn to the nonn9 pꝰerste anone
Come nerꝰer ꝸser pꝰerste com nerꝰer ꝸser Iohn
Tell us such thyngꝭes as may ourꝰer hert glade
Be mery thouȝe þu ryde on a Iade
That theyȝe thi horse be foule or lene
Yf he woll ꝸserue the rekke not a bene
Loke that thi hert be mery euꝰermo
Ȝys oste quoth he so mot y ryde or goo
And þus his tale told to us euꝰerychone
This swete preste this godeman ꝸser Iohn

l.hi: The tale of þe nonn9 preste ;

div.l: A Pore wydow somdele stope in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a cotage
Bysyde a grove stondynge in a dale
This wydow of which y tolde yow my tale
Sythen that day that sche last was a wyfe
In pacyence lad sche hur lyfe
For lytell was hur catel and hur rent
By husbondry of such as god hur sent
Sche fonde hur selfe and eke hur doughtꝰers two
Thre large sowys had sche and no mo
Thre kyne and eke a schep þtat hight malle
Full sote was hur boure and her halle
In which sche ete many a sclendur mele
Of poynant sause hur neded neuꝰer a dele
No deynte mossell passed hur throte
Hur dyette was acordyng to hur cote
Replecio ne made hur neuꝰer seke
A Tempur dyett was all hur fysyk
And excersyf and her suffyceauns
The goute lettud hur no thyng to daunse
Ne poplexye schent nought hur hede
Ne wyne drank sche noþer white ne rede
Hur bord was ꝸserued most wyth white ⁊ blak
Mylke and broun bred in which sche fond no lak
Seynid Bakou and somtyme a ney or twey
For sche was as maner of a deye
A Gardeyn had sche enclosed al aboute
With stykk9 and a drye dyche withoute
In which sche had a kok hight Chaunteclerꝰer
In alle the Cuntrey of Crowyng ne was his perꝰer
Well sykererꝰer was þe crowyng in his logge
Then ys a clokke or an abbey Orloge
By naturꝰer he knewe ascencyoun
Of equynoxyall of that toun
For when grees xv werꝰer descended
Then knewe he hit myȝt not be amended
His kombe was redder þn Corall
And bateld as hit were a Castel wall
Y lyke azurꝰer werꝰer his legg9us his toen
His bylle was blak as Iette hit schone
His naylles white as þe lylly flourꝰer
And lyke Burnysched gold was his colourꝰer
This gentel kok had in his gouꝰernaunce
Seven henn9 for to don his plesaunce
Which were his sustren and his ꝑperamorurs
And wonder lyke to hym as of coloures
And which feyrest hewed vnder throte
Was clepud Damesel ꝐPertilote
Chaunteclerꝰer her loued and ioy to her hem syng
Whan that þe bryght sonne gan to sprynge
In swete acorde my lefe ys fure on lond
For thylke tyme as y haue vnderstond
Bestꝭes and brydd9 kowde speke and synge
And so byfell in the dawnyng
As Chaunteclerꝰer among his wyues alle
Sate on his perche as hit was in the halle
And nexte hym sate fayr ꝑpertylote
And chauntecler gan grone in his throte
As a man þat þat in his dreme dreched sor
And when that ꝑpertelote thus herde hy rore
Sche was a gaste and seid hert derꝰer
What eyleth yow to grone in this manerꝰer
Ye ben a veray sleper fy for schame
And he answerd and seid þ9 madame
I pray yow þat ye take hit not agrefe
By god ye mette that y was in such myschefe
Right now þat yet my hert ys sorꝰer afryght
Now god quoth he my steven rede aright
And kepe my body oute of foule pꝰerson
Me mette that y romed up and doun
With in your yerde wher as y sawh a beste
Was lyke a hounde and wold haue made a reste
Vp on my body and wold haue had me dede
His colour was bytwyxe white and rede
And typped was his tayle and both his eres
With blak vnlyke þe remnaute of his herys
His snoute small with glowyng yȝen twey
Yet for his loke almost for ferde y deyȝe
This caused my gronyng doutelesse
Avoy quoth sche fye on yow hertelesse
Allas quoth sche for by god þtat above
Now haue ye loste my herte and my love
I kan not love a koward by my feith
For certes what so any man seith
We desyren yf hit myȝte be
To haue husbond9 hardy wyse and fre
And secre ne no nygard ne no fole
Ne hym that is a gast of euꝰery tole
No none avoutry by god þtat above
How durst ye seyn for schame vn to yorur love
That any thing myght make yow aferd
Haue ye no mann9 hert and haue a berd
For Catou seith be not aferd of dremes
Therfore plukke up yorur hert and flee fro þe bemes
Of mony oþꝰer men of auctorite
Then euꝰer katou was so mot y the
That all þe reuerse seyn of this sentence
And haue wel founde by exꝑperience
That dremes be signyficacouns
As wel of ioy as of Tribulacouns
That folke enduren in this lyf pꝰersent
Ther nedeth not to make of this none Argument
The veray pꝰerfe scheweth hit in dede
One of the grettest auctourꝰer of drede
¶ Sayth thus that somtyme ij felow9 went
On pylgimage in ful goode Entent
And happed so they come in to a toun
Wherꝰer as therꝰer was such congregacoun
Of pepull eke and of streyte herbygage
That þey ne fonde as mych as is a Cotage
In which þey myȝte both y logged be
Therfore they most of necessyte
As for that nyȝte departe of Company
And yche of hem gooth in to his ostelery
And toke his loggyng as hit wold falle
That one of hem was logged in a stalle
For in a yerd with oxen of the plowe
That oþꝰer man was logged well y nowh
As was his aventur or fortune
That us gouꝰerneth all in comune
And so by felle long or hit werꝰer day
This man mette in his bedde there he lay
How þat his felow gan on hym calle
And sayd allas for in an oxe stalle
This nyȝte schal y be marthred þꝰer y lye
Now helpe me derꝰer broder or y dyȝe
In all hast come to me he sayd
This man oute of his slepe for feerꝰer abrayed
But when that he was waken oute of his slepe
He turneth hym and taketh of this no kepe
Hym thought his dreme but avanyte
Thus twyes in his slepyng dremed he
And at þe thrydde tyme yette his felawe
Come as he thought y am now y slawe
Byholde my blody wound9 depe and wyde
Aryse up erely in the morow tyde
And at the westgate of the toun quoth he
A kartefull of dong þꝰer schal þu see
In which his body is hydde full piriuely
Doo that karte to Arresten piriuely
My gold kaused my murther soth to seyn
And told hym euꝰery poynte how he was slayn
With a full pytous fase pale of hewe
And truste well vp on his dreme he fond trewe
For in the morn as sone as hit was day
To his felow9 Inne he gooth his way
And when he com to this oxe wall
After his Felowe he bygan to calle
The Osteler answerd hym anone
And said ꝸser youre felaw ys goon
As sone as day he wente oute of the toun
This man gan falle in gret suspeccyoun
Remembryng on his dremes that he mette
And forth he gooth he wold no lengꝰer lette
Vn to þe westgate of þe toun and fond
A donge carte as he went to dong þe lond
That was arayed in the same wyse
As ye haue herd þe dede man devyse
And with a hardy hert he gan to crye
Vengeaunce and Iustys of this vyleny
My felawe murthred ys this same nyȝte
And in this carte gapyng he lyeth upright
The dede man þat murthred was all newe
O blyssefull god þat so Iuste art and trewe
Lo how þat þu bywreyest murther alwey
Murther woll oute þat see we day by day
Murther is so wlatsom and abhomynable
To god þat is so Iuste and resonable
That he ne woll suffre hit heled be
Thouȝe he abyde a yere two or thre
Murther woll oute this ys my conclusyon
And right anone mynystꝰers of the toun
Haue take the carter and sore hym peyned
And eke þe osteler so sore hym gyned
That they byknewe her wykkednesse anone
And werꝰer hanged by the nek bon
Her may men see that dremes be to drede
And certez in the same boke as y rede
Right in the next Chapiter I rede of this
Y Sabbe not so haue y ioy or Blysse
¶ Two men that wolden haue passed þe see
For certeyn cause in to Ferrꝰer cuntre
Yf that þe wynde ne had be contrary
That made hem in a Cyte for to tarye
That stode full mery upon the hauen syde
But on a day ayeynst þe Eventyde
The wynde gan blowe and chaunge as he luste
Iolyf and glad þey went to rest
And cast hem full erly to sayle
But herken how o man fel in gret ꝑperayle
That one of hem in slepyng as he lay
Hym mette a wonder dreme ayeynst þe day
Hym thouȝte a man stode by his bedde syde
And hy comaunded þat he schuld abyde
And sayd hym thus yf þu to morow wende
Thow schall be dreynt my tale ys at an ende
He woke and told his felow what he mette
And parayed hym his vyage for to lette
And for that day he preyed for to abyde
His felaw that lay by his bedd9 syde
Gan for to lawh and skorned ful fast
No dreme quoth he may myn hert gast
That y woll lette for to doo my thyngꝭes
I sette not a strawe by dremyngꝭes
For sweuens ben but vanytees and Iapes
Men dreme alwey of owles and apes
And of many a mase þꝰerwith all
Men dreme of thingꝭes þtat neuꝰer schal fall
But sythen y see þu wolt herꝰer abyde
And thus forslowthen wylfully þi tyde
God wote hit reweth me and haue god day
And thus he toke his leve and went his way
And ar that he had halfe his course sayled
Not y not why ne what meschaunse hit ayled
But casuelly the schipp9 bothom rente
And Schipp and man vnder þe watꝰer went
In sight of othur schipp9 hy bysyde
That with hym sayled at þe same tyde
And þꝰerfore he seid ꝐPertelot so derꝰer
By such ensaumplez olde mayst þu lerꝰer
That no man schuld be to rechelesse
Of dremes for y say þe douteles
That many a dreme full sore is to drede
¶ Lo in the lyfe of seynt kenelme y rede
That was kenulphes son þe nobul kyng
Of Mertenrike how kenelme met a thyng
A lytel or he was murthred on a day
His murther in a vysyon he say
His norys hy expowned euꝰerydell
His sweuen and bad hy for to kepe hy well
For tresou but he was seven yere old
And therfore lytel tale hath he told
Of any dreme so holly was his hert
By god y had lever than my schurte
That ye had herd his legend as haue y
Dame ꝑpertelote y sey yow truly
Maccobeus that write avysyou
In Affrike of þe worthy Cypryou
Affermeth dremes and seith þꝰer ben
Warnyng of thyngꝭes þtat men aftꝰer seen
And furthermorꝰer y paray yow loketh well
The olde testament of danyel
Yf he helde dremes of any vanyte
Rede eke of Ioseph and ye schal se
Wheþꝰer dremez ben somtyme y sey not alle
Warnyng of thyngꝭes þat schull aftꝰer falle
¶ Loke eke of Egipt þe kyng pharao
His Baker and his Boteler also
Wheþꝰer þey ne felte none effect in dremes
Who so woll seke þe acte of sondry Remes
May rede of dremes many a wonder thyng
¶ Lo Cresus which þat was of lyde kynge
Mette he not that he sette on a tre
Which signyfied he schuld an honged be
¶ Lo here of Dromachia Ectors wyfe
That day that Ector schuld lette his lyfe
Sche dremed on þe same nyȝte byforne
How that þe lyf of Ector schulde be lorne
Yf he that day went to Batayle
Sche warned hym but hit myȝtt not avayle
He went for to fight nathelese
But he was slayn of Achilles
But that tale ys all to long to dwelle
And eke hit ys forth day9 y may not al tell
¶ Now lete us speke of myrth and stynte all this
Madame ꝑpertelote so haue y blysse
That y defye both sweven and dreme
And with þat word he flewe doun fro þe beme
For hit was day and eke his henn9 alle
And with a chukke he gan his henn9 to calle
Leve y this Chaunteclerꝰer in his pastur
And after woll y tell of his auenture
When the moneth in which þs world bygan
That hight March when god furst made man
Chaunteclers gretely in his hiȝe piride
His seven wyves walken by his syde
And krewe Fresschely and made solace
But sodenly hym fell a sory cas
A Cole foxe full of sleyght and Iniquyte
That in the grove had wouned yeres thre
By hyȝe ymagynacyoun afore cast
The same nyȝt thorou oute the hogg9us stygh Brast
In to the yerd þꝰer Chaunteclerꝰer þe feyre
Was wonte and eke his wyves to repayre
And in a bedde of wortes stylle he lay
Tyll hit was passed vndren of þe day
Waytyng his tyme on chaunteclerꝰer to falle
As gladly don þese homycyders alle
That in awayte lyggen to murther men
O Chaunteclerꝰer cursed be þe morow þu flewe fro the beeme
Full well werꝰer þu warned by thi dremes
That ylke day was ꝑperylous to the
But that god afore wote mot nedes be
I woll not haue a doo with such materꝰer
My tale ys of a kok as ye schull herꝰer
That toke his counsell of his wyfe with sorowe
To walken in þe yerd on þe morow
That he had mette þe dreeme þat y tolde
Wymens counsell be oft full cold
Wymens counsell brought us furst to woo
And made Adam fro ꝑperadyse to goo
There as he was full mery and well at ese
But for y not whom y myȝt dysplese
Yf I counsel of women wold blame
Passe ouꝰer y seid hit in my game
Rede auctorurs where þey trete in such manerꝰer
And what þey sey of women therꝰer
Those ben the kokk9 word9 ⁊ not myn
I kan no harme of women devyne
Chaunteclerꝰer sange mery and cast up his yȝe
Amonge þe wort9 on a Botꝰerflye
He was ware of this foxe lay full lowe
Nothynge ne luste hym than for to crowe
But cryed anone Cok kok and up he sterte
As a man þtat werꝰer afrayed in his hert
Chaunteclerꝰer wolde haue fledde but þat þe foxe anone
Sayd gentel ꝸser what wol ye doon
Be ye affrayed of me þtat am yorur frende
Certes ꝸser than be ye vnhende
Yf y to yow wold harme or vylenye
Y am not come yorur counsel to aspye
But treuly the cause of my cōmmynge
Was onely to herken how þat ye synge
For truly ye haue a mery steven
As an Aungel hath þat is in heuen
But for men spekyth of syngyng y wol sey
So mot y brouke myn yȝen twey
Save ye y herd neuꝰer man so synge
As dydde youre fadur in the mornynge
Certes hit was of hert all þat he songe
And for to make his voyse þe more strong
He wold so peyne hym that with both his yȝen
He most wynke so lowde he dydde cryen
And stonden on his typtoes þꝰerwith all
And streche forth his nekke long and small
And eke now for yorur fader loue let see
How Fressch kan ye syng for charyte
Lete se kan ye yourꝰer fadur counterfete
This Chauntelclerꝰer his whyngꝭes gan to bete
As a man þtat kowde not his tresou aspye
So was he Ravyssched with his flatery
Allas ye lordes many a false flatourꝰer
Ys in your courtes and many a losengeourꝰer
That plesen you more by my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse to you seith
Redeth ecclesiaste of Flaterye
Beth ware ye lord9 of hur trecherye
This chaunteclerꝰer stode hiȝe upon his toes
Strecchyng his nekke and holdyng his yȝen close
And gan to crowen lowde for the nones
And þe foxe dau Russell stert up at ones
And by the Gargage hente haunteclerꝰer
And on his Bak toward þe wode hym berꝰer
For ȝet was þꝰer no man hy sewed
O destenye þu mayst not be eschewed
But grete schryghtes and grete noyse
Maden þe henn9 in the close
When they siȝe of Chaunteclerꝰer that sight
But alder lowdest dam ꝐPertelot schright
Tho this sely and her doughtꝰers two
Herd þe hennes cryen and make woo
And oute at þe dorꝰer sterte þey anone
And sowh þe foxe to the grove goon
And bare up on his bakke þe kok alwey
And cryed oute harrow and weyleawey
A ha þe foxe and aftꝰer hy þey Ran
And eke with staves many a noþꝰer man
Ran colle oure dogge Talbot and Garlond
And Malkyn with her dystaf in her hond
Ran kowe and kalfe and eke þe veray hogg9us
That were sore aferd for berkyng of þe dogg9us
And castynge of men and women eke
They Ran so hem thouȝte hur hert to breke
They yelled as fend9 dou in hell
The dogg9us cryed as men wold hem quelle
Oute of the hyves come the swarme of Bees
The Gees of feere flowen ouꝰer the trees
So hido9us was þe noyse a benedicite
So berked þe dogg9us so cryed sche
With all þe noyse þey kowde þey made on þe foxe
Of bras þey brought bemes and also of Boxe
Of horne of boon in which þey powped
And þꝰerwith all þey schryght and schowted
This Cok þat lay on the foxe bakke
In all his drede vn to þe foxe spake
And seid ꝸser yf y werꝰer as ye
Yette schuld y sey as wysse god help me
Turne ayeyn ye proude churles alle
A veray pestylence on yow falle
Now am y come vn to this wode syde
Magre yorur hedes þe kok schal herꝰer abyde
I woll hym ete in feith and þat anone
The Foxe onswerd in feith hit schall be don
And as he spake þat word all sodeynly
This Cok brake fro his mouth delyuꝰerly
And hiȝe upon a tre he fleyȝe anone
And when þe foxe sawh he was goon
Allas quoth he o Chaunteclerꝰer allas
I haue quoth he don to yow trespasse
In as mych as y made yow aferd
When y yow hente and brought oute of þe yerd
But ꝸser y dydde hit not in no wykked entent
Cometh doun and y schal tel yow what y ment
I schall sey soth so god helpe me so
Nay than quoth he y byschrewe us both two
And furst y schrewe my self blod ⁊ bonys
Yf þu bygyle me ofter then onys
Thow schalt no morꝰer with thi flaterye
Do me synge and wynke with myn yȝe
For he þat wynketh when he schuld see
As wyssely god lette hym neuꝰer thee
Nay quoth þe foxe god gyffe hy myschaunse
That is so vndyscrete of gouernaunce
That Iangleth when he schuld hold his pees
Lo such is for to be rechelesse
And neclygent and truste on flaterye
But ye that holden this foly
As of a foxe a kok and a henne
Taketh þe moralyte gode men
For Seynt poule seith alle that writen ys
To oure doctryn writen hit ys
Taketh þe frute and lette þe chaffe be stylle
Now goode god yf hit be thi wylle
Thorou thi grace make us all gode men
And bryng us to his Blysse Amen

div.l: (base) And here folweth the prologe of the Manciples tale

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Narrat
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer
(base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun
(base) That with his syngyng walled that Citee
(base) Koude neuere syngen half so wel as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelieste man
(base) That is or was sith that the world bigan
(base) What nedeth it hise fetures to discryue
(base) For in this world was noon so fair on lyue
(base) He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse
(base) Of honour and of parfit worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was flour of Bachelrye
(base) As wel in fredom as in Chiualrye
(base) For his desport in signe eek of victorie
(base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a Crowe
(base) Which in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
(base) Whit was this Crowe as is a Snow whit swan
(base) And contrefete the speche of euery man
(base) He kowde whan he sholde telle a tale
(base) Ther with in al this world no nyghtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
(base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence

div.l: (base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence
(base) Saue oonly that the sothe if I shal sayn
(base) Ialous he was and wolde han kept hire fayn
(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be
(base) And so is euery wight in swich degree
(base) But al for naught for it auaileth noght
(base) A good wyf that is clene in werk and thoght
(base) Sholde nat be kept in noon awayt certayn
(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn
(base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be
(base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyues
(base) But now to purpos as I first bigan
(base) This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan
(base) To plesen hire wenynge for swich plesaunce
(base) And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
(base) That no man sholde han put hym from hire grace
(base) But god it woot ther may no man embrace
(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may
(base) Although his Cage of gold be neuer so gay
(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse
(base) For euere this bryd wol doon his bisynesse
(base) To eschape out of his Cage if he may
(base) His libertee this bryd desireth ay
(base) Lat take a Cat and fostre hym wel with Milk

div.l: (base) And tendre flessh and make his couche of silk
(base) And lat hym seen a Mous go by the wal
(base) Anon he weyueth Milk and flessh and al
(base) And euery deyntee that is in that hous
(base) Swich appetit hath he to ete a Mous
(base) Lo heere hath lust his domynacioun
(base) And appetit flemeth discrecioun
(base) A she wolf hath also a vileyns kynde
(base) The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
(base) And leest of reputacioun that wol she take
(base) In tyme whan hire lust to han a make
(base) Alle thise ensamples speke I by thise men
(base) That ben vntrewe but no thyng by wommen
(base) For men han euere a likerous appetit
(base) On lower thyng to parformen hir delit
(base) Than on hire wyues be they neuer so faire
(base) Ne neuer so trewe ne so debonaire
(base) Flessh is so newfangel with meschaunce
(base) That we ne konne in no thyng han plesaunce
(base) That sowneth in to vertu any while
(base) This Phebus which that thoughte vpon no gile
(base) Deceyued was for al his iolitee
(base) For vnder hym another hadde she
(base) A man of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to Phebus in comparisoun
(base) The moore harm is it happeth ofte so

(base) And so bifel whan Phebus was absent
(base) His wyf anon hath for hire lemman sent
(base) Hir lemman certes this is a knauyssh speche
(base) Foryeueth it me and that I yow biseche
(base) The wise Plato seith as ye may rede

div.l: (base) If men shal telle proprely a thyng
(base) The word moot cosyn be to the werkyng
(base) I am a boystous man right thus seye I
(base) Ther nys no difference trewely
(base) Bitwix a wyf that is of heigh degree
(base) If of hire body deshoneste she be
(base) And a poore wenche oother than this
(base) If it so be they werke bothe amys
(base) But that the gentile in estat aboue
(base) She shal be clepid his lady as in loue
(base) And for that oother is a poore womman
(base) She shal be clepid his wenche or his lemman
(base) And god it woot myn owene deere brother
(base) Men leyn that oon as lowe as lyth that oother
(base) Right so bitwix a titlelees tiraunt
(base) And an Outlawe or a theef erraunt

(base) To Alisandre was told this sentence

(base) By force of meyne for to sleen doun right
(base) And brennen hous and hoom and make al playn

(base) And for the Outlawe hath but smal meynee

(base) But for I am a man noght textuel
(base) I wol noght telle of textes neuer a del

(base) Whan Phebus wyf hadde sent for hire lemman
(base) Anon they wroghte al hire lust volage
(base) The white Crowe that heng ay in the Cage
(base) Biheld hir werk and seyde neuer a word
(base) And when that hoom was come Phebus the lord
(base) This Crowe sang Cokkow Cokkow Cokkow
(base) What bryd quod Phebus what song syngestow
(base) Ne were thow wont so myrily to synge
(base) That to myn herte it was a reioysynge
(base) To here thy voys allas what song is this
(base) By God quod he I synge nat amys
(base) Phebus quod he for al thy worthynesse
(base) For al thy beautee and thy gentillesse
(base) For al thy song and al thy Mynstralcye
(base) For al thy waityng blered is thyn eye
(base) With oon of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to thee in comparisoun
(base) The montaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
(base) For in thy bed thy wif I sey hym et cetera

div.l: (base) What wol ye moore the Crowe anon hym tolde
(base) By sadde toknes and by wordes bolde
(base) How that his wyf hadde doon hire lecherye
(base) Hym to gret shame and to gret vileynye
(base) And tolde hym ofte he say it with hise eyen
(base) This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen
(base) And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo
(base) His bowe he bente and sette ther Inne a flo
(base) And in his Ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to sayn
(base) For sorwe of which he brak his Mynstralcye
(base) Bothe harpe and Lute and Gyterne and Sawtrye
(base) And eek he brak hise arwes and his bowe
(base) And after that thus spak he to the Crowe
(base) Traytour quod he with tonge of Scorpioun
(base) Thow hast me broght to my confusioun
(base) Allas that I was wroght why nere I ded
(base) O deere wyf o gemme of lustihed
(base) That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
(base) Now lystow ded with face pale of hewe
(base) Ful giltlees that dorste I swere ywys
(base) O rakel hand to doon so foule amys
(base) O trouble wit o Ire recchelees
(base) That vnauysed smytest giltlees
(base) O wantrust ful of fals suspecioun
(base) Where was thy wit and thy discrecioun
(base) O euery man be war of rakelnesse
(base) Ne trowe ye no thyng withouten strong witnesse
(base) Smyt nat to soone er that ye witen why
(base) And beth auysed wel and sobrely
(base) Er ye do any execucioun
(base) Vpon youre Ire for suspecioun

div.l: (base) Allas a thousand folk hath rakel Ire
(base) Fully fordoon or broght hem in the Myre
(base) Allas for sorwe I wol my seluen sle
(base) And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
(base) I wol thee quyte anon thy false tale
(base) Thow songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale
(base) Now shaltow false theef thy song forgon
(base) And eek thy white fetheres euerichon
(base) Ne neuere in al thy lyf ne shaltow speke
(base) Thus shal men on a traytour ben awreke
(base) Thow and thyn ofspryng euere shul be blake
(base) Ne neuere swete noyse shul ye make
(base) But euere crye agayn tempest and rayn
(base) In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn
(base) And to the Crowe he stirte and that anon
(base) And pulled hise white fetheres euerichon
(base) And made hym blak and refte hym al his song
(base) And eek his speche and out at dore hym slong
(base) Vnto the deuel which I hym bitake

(base) Lordynges by this ensample I yow preye
(base) Beth war and taketh kepe what I seye
(base) Ne telleth neuere no man in youre lyf
(base) How that another man hath dight his wyf
(base) He wol yow haten mortally certeyn
(base) Daun Salomon as wise clerkes seyn
(base) Techeth a man to kepen his tonge wel
(base) But as I seyde I nam nat textuel
(base) But nathelees thus taughte me my dame
(base) My sone thenk on the Crowe agoddes name
(base) My sone keep wel thy tonge and kepe thy freend
(base) A wikke tonge is worse than a feend
(base) My sone from a feend men may hem blesse

div.l: (base) For man sholde hym auyse what he speeke
(base) My sone ful ofte for to muche speche
(base) Hath many a man ben spilt as clerkes teche
(base) But for litel speche auysely
(base) Is no man shent to speke generally
(base) My sone thy tonge sholdestow restreyne
(base) At alle tymes but whan thow doost thy peyne
(base) To speke of god in honour and prayere
(base) The firste vertu sone if thow wolt leere

(base) Thus lernen children whan that they ben yonge

div.l: bY that the mauncypııll had his tale ended
The sonne fro the south syde ys descended
So lowe þat hit was to my sight
Degrees xxix of hight
Oure lord seid lordyngꝭes euꝰerychone
Now lakketh us no tale mor than one
Fullfylled ys my sentence and my degre
Who schall telle a tale now lete see
Almost fulfylled ys my ordynance
I paray to god gyffe hym goode chaunse
That telleth this tale to us lustely
Sir preste quoth he art þu a Vikery
Art þu a ꝑpersoūn sey soth by þi fey
Be what þu be breke not oure pley
For euꝰery man save þu hath told his tale
Vnbokle and schewe what is in thi male
For truly me thenketh by thi chere
That þou schuld knytte up well a grete mater
Tell som fable anone for kokkꝭes bones
This ꝐPersou answerd all at onys
Thow getest fable none y told for me
For Poule þat writeth vn to Tymothe
Repreven hem þat wayven sothfastenesse
And tellen folies and such Wrecchednesse
Whi schuld y schewen draffe oute of my fest
When y may schewen whete yf me lyste
For y woll sey yf ye lyste to here
Moralyte and vertuous mater
So þat ye woll gyffe me audyence
Y woll full fayn at crystꝭes reuꝰerence
Dou yow plesaunce lefall as y kan
But trusteth well y am a suthren man
I kan not gest ram rum ruf by lettꝰer
Ne god wote ryme hold y but lytel bettꝰer
And þꝰerfore yf yow lyst y woll you not glose
I woll you tell a mery tale in prose
To knytte up all this Fest and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace wytte me sende
To schewe yow þe wey in this vyage
Of thilk gloryo9us pylgrymage
That hight Ierlm Celestyall
And yf ye vouchsafe anone ye schall
Bygyn upon my tale for which y pꝰerye
Tell your avyse y kan no bettꝰer sey
But nathelese this meditacoun
Y putte ay vnder coreccyoun
Of clerkꝭes for y am not text well
I take but þe sentence trusteth well
Therfor y make protestacoun
That y woll stonde to correccyoun
Vp on this word we haue assented sone
For as us semed hit was to done
To enden in som vertuo9us sentence
And for to yeve hym spase and audience
And bad oure oste schuld to hy sey
That all we to tell his tale hym pꝰery
Our oste had þe word9 for us all
Sir pꝰerste qd he now fayr mot ye byfalle
Telle qd he yorur meditacoun
And hasteth you þe sonne goth a doun

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6o State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne
that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

(base) Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

(base) the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
his synne

(base) the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne
hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng

(base) but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence

(base) Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth
hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

(base) In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde
iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche
ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he
sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule

(base) thanne
is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth
in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to
do penance and neuere moore to do synne

(base) and this sorwe shal ben
in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte

(base) first for man hath
agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt
for he hath agilt his fader celestial

(base) and yet moore sharpe and
poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym
that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle

(base) The causes that oghten moeuen a man to Contricioun been vj
ffirst a man
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
shal remembren hym of hise synnes

(base) but looke
that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret
shame and sorwe for his gilt for Iob seith Synful men doon
werkes worthy of Confessioun

(base) And therfore seith Ezechie I
wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn
herte

(base) And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye
were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god

(base) but
for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of
the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and
foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle

(base) And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte
tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng

(base) and
yet be ye fouler for youre longe contynuynge in synne and
youre synful vsage for which ye been roten in youre synne
as a beest in his donge

(base) swiche manere of thoughtes maken
a man haue shame of his synne and no delit as god seyth
by the prophete Ezechiel

(base) ye shal remembre yow of youre
weyes and they shullen displese yow soothly synnes been
the weyes that leden folk to helle

(base) The seconde cause that oghte
make a man to han desdeyn of synne is this that as seith
Seint Peter who so that dooth synne is thral of synne and
synne put a man in greet thraldam

(base) And therfore seith the
prophete Ezechiel I wente sorweful in desdayn of my self
Certes wel oghte a man haue desdayn of synne and with
drawe hym fro that thraldom and vileynye

(base) And lo what
seith Seneca in this matere he seith thus though I wiste
that god neither god ne man ne sholde neuere kNowe it yet
wolde Ihaue desdayn for to do synne

(base) And the same Seneca also
seith Iam born to gretter thynges than to be thral to my body or than for to maken of my body a thral

(base) ne a fouler thral
may no man ne womman make of his body than for to yeue his
body to synne

(base) al were it the fouleste cherl or the fouleste womman
that lyueth and leest of value yet is he thanne moore foul and
moore in seruitute

(base) euere fro the hyer degree that man falleth the
moore is he thral and moore to god and to the world vil and abhomynable

(base) O goode god wel oghte man haue greet desdayn
of synne sith that thurgh synne ther he was fre Now is he
maked bonde

(base) And ther fore seith Seint Augustyn If thow
hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne haue thow
thanne desdayn that thow thy self sholdest do synne

(base) take
reward of thy value that thow ne be to foul to thy self

(base) Allas wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn to ben seruantz
and thralles

to synne and soore ben ashamed of hem self

(base) that god
of his endelees goodnesse hath set hem in heigh estat or yeuen hem wit strengthe of body heele beautee prosperitee

(base) and boghte hem fro the deeth with his herte blood that they so
vnkyndely agayns his gentilesse quyten hym so vileynsly
to slawghtre of hir owene soules

(base) O goode god ye wommen that been of so greet beautee remembreth yow of the

(base) likneth a fair womman that is
a fool of hire body lyk to a ryng of gold that were in the

(base) for right as a Sowe wroteth in euerich
ordure so wroteth she hire beaute in stynkynge ordure of
synne

(base) The thridde cause that oughte moeue a man to
Contricion is drede of the day of dome and of the horrible peynes of helle

(base) For as Seint Ierome seith At euery
tyme that me remembreth of the day of dome I quake

(base) for
whan I ete and drynke or what so that I do euere semeth
me that the trompe sowneth in myn ere

(base) Riseth ye vp that ben
dede and cometh to the Iugement

(base) O goode god muchel
oghte a man to drede swich a Iugement ther as we shullen ben alle as seith Seint Poul biforn the Sete of oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) where as he shal maken a general congregacioun where as no man may ben absent

(base) for certes there
ne auaileth noon essoyne ne excusacioun

(base) and nat oonly
that oure defautes shullen be Iuged but eek that alle oure
werkes shullen openly be kNowe

(base) and as that seith Seint
Bernard ther ne shal no pletynge auaile ne no sleighte We
shullen yeue rekenynge of euerich ydel word

(base) there shul we han
a Iuge that may nat ben deceyued ne corrupt and why for
certes alle oure thoghtes ben descouered as to hym ne for prayere ne for mede he wol nat ben corrupt

(base) and therfore seith Salomon the wrathe of god ne wol nat spare no wight for prayere ne for yifte And therfore at the day of dome ther nys
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
noon
hope to escape

(base) Wherfore as seith Seint Anselme Ful gret
anguisse shullen the synful folk haue at that tyme

(base) ther
shal the stierne and wrothe Iuge sitte aboue and vnder hym
the horrible pit of helle open to destroye hym that moot bikNowen
hise synnes whiche synnes openly ben shewed biforn god

(base) and on the left syde mo deueles
than herte may bithynke for to harye and drawe the synful soules to the pyne of helle

(base) and with Inne the hertes of
folk shal be the bityng conscience and with oute forth shal

(base) whider shal thanne the wrechched synful man fle to hyde hym certes he may nat hyde hym he moste come forth and shewe hym

seith Seint Ierome the erthe shal caste hym out of hym

(base) Now soothly who so wel
remembreth hym of thise thynges I gesse that his synne
shal nat torne hym in delit but to gret sorwe for drede

(base) And therfore seith Iob to god Suffre lord that I may a while biwayle and wepe er I go with
oute returnynge to the dirke lond couered with the derknesse of deeth

(base) to the lond of mysese and of derknesse where as
is the shadwe of deeth where as ther is noon ordre or

(base) Lo here
may ye seen that Iob preyde respit a while to biwepe and
wayle his trespas for soothly o day of respit is bettre
than al the tresor of this world

(base) And for as muche as a
man may acquyte hym self biforn god by penitence in
this world and nat by tresor therfore sholde he preye to

his trespas

(base) for certes al the sorwe that a man myghte
make fro the bigynnyng of the world nys but a litel
thyng at regard of the sorwe of helle

(base) The cause why
that Iob clepeth helle the lond of derknesse

(base) vnderstondeth
that he clepeth it lond or erthe for it is stable and neuere shal faile
dirkfor he that is in helle hath defaute of light material

(base) for
certes the derke light that shal come out of the fyr that euere shal
brenne shal turne hym al to peyne that is in helle for it sheweth hym to the horrible deueles that hym tormenten

(base) couered
with the derknesse of deeth that is to seyn that he that is in helle
shal haue defaute of the sighte of god for certes the sighte of
god is the lyf pardurable

(base) The derknesse of deeth ben the synnes that the wrecched man hath doon whiche that destourben hym
to se the face of god right as a dirk clowde bitwixe vs and
the sonne

(base) Lond of myseise by cause that ther ben iij manere
of defautes agayns iij thynges that folk of this world han
in this present lyf that is to seyn honours delices and rychesses
(base) Agayns honour han they in helle shame and confusioun

(base) for wel ye woot that men clepen honour the reuerence that man
dooth to man but in helle is noon honour ne reuerence for certes
namoore reuerence shal be doon to a kyng than to a knaue

(base) for
which god seith by the prophete Ieremye thilke folk that me despisen shulle ben in despit

(base) honour is eek clepid greet lordshipe
ther shal no wight seruen oother but of harm and torment
Honour is eek clepid greet dignytee and heighnesse but in helle
shul they ben al for troden of deueles

(base) As god seith the horrible deueles shullen goon and comen vp on the heuedes of dampned folk And this is for as muche as the heyere that they were
in this present lyf the moore shulle they ben abated and defouled
in helle

(base) Agayns the richesse of this world shul they han
myseyse of pouerte and this pouerte shal be in iiij thynges

(base) In defaute of tresor of which that Dauid seith the riche folk that
embraceden and oneden al hir herte to tresor of this world shulle slepen in the slepynge of deeth and no thyng ne shal they
fynden in hire handes of al hire tresor

(base) And moore ouer the
Misayse of helle shal ben in defaute of mete and drynke

(base) for
god seith thus by Moyses they shul ben wasted with honger
and the bryddes of helle shul deuouren hem with bitter deeth
and the galle of the dragon shal ben hire drynke and the
venym of the dragon hire morsels

(base) And forther ouer hire
Miseyse shal ben in defaute of clothyng for they shullen ben
naked in body as of clothyng saue the fyr in which they
brenne and othere filthes

(base) and naked shul they ben of soule of
alle manere vertues which that is the clothyng of soule where
ben thanne the gaye robes and the softe shetes

and the smale shertes

(base) Lo what seith god of hem by the prophete Ysaye that vnder hem

wormes of helle

(base) And forther ouer hire myseyse shal ben
in defaute of frendes for he is nat pouere that hath goode frendes but there is no freend

(base) for neither god ne no creature shal
ben freend to hem and euerich of hem shal haten oother with
deedly hate

(base) the sones and the doghtren shullen rebellen agayns
fader and moder and kynrede agayns kynrede and chiden and
despisen euerich of hem oother bothe day and nyght as god
seith by the prophete Michias

(base) And the louynge children that whilom loueden so flesshly euerich oother wolden euerich of hem
eten oother if they myghte

(base) for how sholde they louen hem to-
gidre in the peyne of helle whan they hateden euerich of
hem oother in the prosperitee of this lyf

(base) for truste wel hire
flesshly loue was dedly hate as seith the prophete Dauid
who so that loueth wikkednesse he hateth his soule

(base) and who
so hateth his owene soule certes he may loue noon oother
wight in no manere

(base) and therfore in helle is no solas ne
no frendshipe but euere the moore flesshly kynredes that ben
in helle the moore cursynges the moore chidynges and the
moore dedly hate ther is among hem

(base) And forther ouer
they shul haue defaute of alle manere delices for certes
